meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Nariai, Hidekazu.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Hiroshima Univ., Takehara (Japan). Research Inst. for Theoretical Physics

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On characteristic turbulent quantities at the bounce epoch in our hadron-dominated model of the universe

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HYDRODYNAMICS; METRICS; NUCLEAR MATTER; TURBULENCE; UNIVERSE; VELOCITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; MECHANICS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The phenomenological modification of Einstein's field equations is discussed. In a previous paper, the dynamical equations for the mean-value quantities of a turbulent field were derived. So far as the bounce epoch of the universe is concerned, three characteristic mean-value quantities <lh.lh>sub( )sup(1/2), <v2>sub( )sup(1/2), and <K2>sub( )sup(1/2) corresponding to metric, velocity, and density fluctuations are compatible with the basic idea, on two simplifying assumptions. The purpose of this note is to examine how the results obtained in the previous paper for the characteristic mean-value quantities in the bounce epoch eta=0 are modified, if one of the assumptions is replaced with a more suitable one, 4-th order approximation together with the hypothesis of joint-normal distribution. Relations in the previous paper were reduced to new forms. The numerical values of x=<lh.lh>sub( )sup(1/2), y=<K2>sub( )sup(1/2), z=<v2>sub( )sup(1/2) were obtained. It is easily seen from the results that there is considerable discrepancy between the second order solution and the 4-th order one, and that the transition to the 4-th order approximation gives smaller values of x and y, and larger values of z. (Kato, T.)

meta.content: January 1974

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOSONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; ORBITS; PRECESSION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Classical solutions of supergravity are obtained by making finite global supersymmetry rotation on known solutions of the field equations of the bosonic sector. The Schwarzschild and the Reissner-Nordstoem solutions of general relativity are extended to various supergravity systems and the modification to the perihelion precession of planets is discussed

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1977

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Covarrubias, G.M. (Queen Elizabeth Coll., London (UK). Dept. of Mathematics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational radiation in Szekeres's quasi-spherical space-times

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 13(9) p. 3023-3028; ISSN 0305-4470; Sep 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY LOSSES; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; MINKOWSKI SPACE; QUADRUPOLE MOMENTS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RADIATIONS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A necessary and sufficient condition for flatness of the quasi-spherical space-times of Szekeres (Commun. Math. Phys.; 41:55 (1975) and Phys. Rev.; D12:2941 (1975)) is given. Using this, the linear approximation of these space-times is considered and it is shown that the third derivatives of the quadrupole moments vanish for matter distribution contained within a comoving surface. Hence the Einstein formula gives zero energy loss due to gravitational radiation. This agrees with other investigations, which have shown that no radiation is present in these space-times. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Smith, A.G.; Will, C.M. (Institute of Theoretical Physics, Department of Physics, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Force on a static charge outside a Schwarzschild black hole

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(6) p. 1276-1284; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Sep 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CHARGED PARTICLES; COULOMB FIELD; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROSTATICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GREEN FUNCTION; MASS RENORMALIZATION; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELECTRIC FIELDS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; RENORMALIZATION

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An exact calculation of the gravitationally induced electrostatic self-force on a charged test particle held stationary outside a Schwarzschild black hole is presented. After mass renormalization, there remains a finite repulsive force proportional to the square of the charge of the particle and to the mass of the black hole. In a local, freely falling frame momentarily at rest with respect to the charge, the repulsive force varies as the inverse cube of the Schwarzschild coordinate distance of the charge from the origin

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On quantum gravitational effects in an isotropic Universe

meta.name: Title
meta.content: O kvantovykh gravitatsionnykh ehffektakh v izotropnoj vselennoj

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki; v. 78(6) p. 2081-2098; ISSN 0044-4510; Jun 1980; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics - JETP (USA).

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; ISOTROPY; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; PERTURBATION THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; RADIATIVE CORRECTIONS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; UNIVERSE; VACUUM POLARIZATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CORRECTIONS; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Vacuum polarization effects induced by an external gravitational field in a systeM of spjnor, scalar or vector mass particles are considered on the basis of the model of conformally-plane time-space. Expressions for the radiative corrections are obtained and the role they play in the theory of gravitation in the asymptotic regions of weak (|Rsub(i)sup(k)|<<msup(2)) and strong (|Rsub(i)sup(k)|>>msup(2)) gravitational fields is analyzed. Formulae for the rate of spontaneous production of real particles by a strong gravitational field are presented in the Appendix as well as formulae for the energy-momentum tensor for real particles in the ultrarelativistic limit. The law of increase of entropy in an ultrarelativistic medium is formulated

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Ipser, J.R. (University of Chicago)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Binding-energy criterion for the dynamical stability of spherical stellar systems in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Astrophysical Journal; v. 238(3) p. 1101-1110; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Jun 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BINDING ENERGY; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; DISTRIBUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUILIBRIUM; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; STABILITY; STAR CLUSTERS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A powerful sufficient condition for the dynamical stability of spherical stellar systems to collisionless spherical perturbations is derived within the framework of general relativity. The derivation proceeds along lines similar to those of an earlier paper devoted to the corresponding Newtonian problem. It begins with the formulation of, and solution to, the problem of determining which relativistic spherical systems maximize locally, at fixed mass-energy, rest mass, and boundary value of the phase density, the value of the phase-space integral of a chosen function of the phase density. It is shown that members of appropriate one-parameter sequences of spherical equilibria cease to maximize their associated integral-functionals at the first maxima of the binding energy along the sequences. A proof is given that a relativistic spherical stellar system in collisionless equilibrium is dynamically stable to collisionless perturbations if it does maximize the unique functional which it extremizes. This implies that members of appropriate equilibrium sequences are stable at least up to the first maximum of the binding energy. This sufficient condition is remarkably strong, because in several studied cases it breaks down at a point which coincides, to within available numerical accuracy, with the calculated point of onset of dynamical instability. This leads to the conjecture that the condition is in fact also generally necessary. If so, an implication would be that general relativity induces spherical dynamical instabilities in certain nearly Newtonian stellar systems. While conceptually important, this would probably be of limited astrophysical interest, since the instability growth times should be quite long

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: f so, an implication would be that general relativity induces spherical dynamical instabilities in certain nearly Newtonian stellar systems. While conceptually important, this would probably be of limited astrophysical interest, since the instability growth times should be quite long

meta.content: January 1980

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="US8018090" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="US8018090" type="journal" rn="12579611"> <publication> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Binding-energy criterion for the dynamical stability of spherical stellar systems in general relativity</title> </titles> <date value="1980-06-15" sici-chronology="19800615">15 Jun 1980</date> <country key="US">United States</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Ipser, J.R.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">University of Chicago</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:12579611</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Astrophysical Journal</title> <title type="abbreviated">Astrophys. J</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0004-637X</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 238(3) p. 1101-1110.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1500" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="01039" assignment="indexer">binding energy</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02642" assignment="indexer">differential equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02716" assignment="indexer">distribution</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03153" assignment="indexer">equilibrium</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09363" assignment="indexer">spherical configuration</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09410" assignment="indexer">stability</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09452" assignment="indexer">star clusters</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02148" assignment="upposted">configuration</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03112" assignment="upposted">energy</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A powerful sufficient condition for the dynamical stability of spherical stellar systems to collisionless spherical perturbations is derived within the framework of general relativity. The derivation proceeds along lines similar to those of an earlier paper devoted to the corresponding Newtonian problem. It begins with the formulation of, and solution to, the problem of determining which relativistic spherical systems maximize locally, at fixed mass-energy, rest mass, and boundary value of the phase density, the value of the phase-space integral of a chosen function of the phase density. It is shown that members of appropriate one-parameter sequences of spherical equilibria cease to maximize their associated integral-functionals at the first maxima of the binding energy along the sequences. A proof is given that a relativistic spherical stellar system in collisionless equilibrium is dynamically stable to collisionless perturbations if it does maximize the unique functional which it extremizes. This implies that members of appropriate equilibrium sequences are stable at least up to the first maximum of the binding energy. This sufficient condition is remarkably strong, because in several studied cases it breaks down at a point which coincides, to within available numerical accuracy, with the calculated point of onset of dynamical instability. This leads to the conjecture that the condition is in fact also generally necessary. If so, an implication would be that general relativity induces spherical dynamical instabilities in certain nearly Newtonian stellar systems. While conceptually important, this would probably be of limited astrophysical interest, since the instability growth times should be quite long</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Lapedes, A.S. (Institute for Advanced Study, School of Natural Sciences, Princeton, New Jersey 08540)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Black-hole uniqueness theorems in Euclidean quantum gravity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(8) p. 1837-1847; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Oct 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; FEYNMAN PATH INTEGRAL; KERR METRIC; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Euclidean section of the classical Lorentzian black-hole solutions has been used in approximating the functional integral in the Euclidean path-integral approach to quantum gravity. In this paper the claim that classical black-hole uniqueness theorems apply to the Euclidean section is disproved. In particular, it is shown that although a Euclidean version of Israel's theorem does provide a type of uniqueness theorem for the Euclidean Schwarzschild solution, a Euclidean version of Robinson's theorem does not allow one to form conclusions about the uniqueness of the Euclidean Kerr solution. Despite the failure of uniqueness theorems, ''no-hair'' theorems are shown to exist. Implications are discussed. A precise mathematical statement of the Euclidean black-hole uniqueness conjecture is made and the proof, left as an unsolved problem in Riemannian geometry

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In 1965 Nariai suggested that the boundary conditions of O'Brien and Synge should be supplemented by an extra equation. It is shown here that Nariai's extra equation reduces to an identity if the O'Brien and Synge boundary conditions are applied. (author)

meta.name: SubjectCategory

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CYLINDRICAL CONFIGURATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Solutions of the Einstein equation for a self-gravitating, irrotational fluid are sought for a cylindrically symmetric metric. The system satisfies the equation of state p + 2Λ = 0, where p is pressure and Λ is the cosmological constant. The complete set of solutions is obtained for Λ not = 0

meta.content: January 1978

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The principal landmarks in the development of general relativity (exclusive of cosmology) during the first 30 years after its founding are presented. The emergence of the new gravitational laws, their experimental consequences and the consequent growth of the present concern with gravitational collapse and black holes are traced. (U.K.)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; DISTRIBUTION FUNCTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; ISOTHERMAL PROCESSES; MASS; NEUTRON STARS; RED SHIFT; STAR MODELS; THEORETICAL DATA

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DATA; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INFORMATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUMERICAL DATA; STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The structures of isothermal cores with extreme relativistic conditions are discussed and central redshifts calculated for polytropic envelopes which have positive distribution function for all possible energies provided that dp/drho<= 1. Choosing an envelope in which the density is a specific function of r and assuming the surface density to be equal to 2 x 1014 g cm-3, the mass of neutron stars has been calculated. The maximum mass of 4.7 Solar Masses is consistent with the results of other authors. (U.K.)

assignment="indexer">star models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="20360" assignment="indexer">theoretical data</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02485" assignment="upposted">data</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field type="valid" key="09459" assignment="upposted">stars</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The structures of isothermal cores with extreme relativistic conditions are discussed and central redshifts calculated for polytropic envelopes which have positive distribution function for all possible energies provided that dp/drho<= 1. Choosing an envelope in which the density is a specific function of r and assuming the surface density to be equal to 2 x 10<sup>14</sup> g cm<sup>-3</sup>, the mass of neutron stars has been calculated. The maximum mass of 4.7 Solar Masses is consistent with the results of other authors. (U.K.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Dynamics of dimensional reduction

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SUPERGRAVITY; TENSORS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In d-dimensional unified theories that, along with gravity, contain an antisymmetric tensor field of rank s-1, preferential compactification of d-s or of s space-like dimensions is found to occur. This is the case in 11-dimensional supergravity where s = 4. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Maeda, Keiichi (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Fundamental Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational collapse of charged dust shell and maximal slicing condition

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 63(2) p. 425-437; ISSN 0033-068X; Feb 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MASS; METRICS; SHELLS; THEORETICAL DATA

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DATA; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The maximal slicing condition is a good time coordinate condition qualitatively when pursuing the gravitational collapse by the numerical calculation. The analytic solution of the gravitational collapse under the maximal slicing condition is given in the case of a spherical charged dust shell and the behavior of time slices with this coordinate condition is investigated. It is concluded that under the maximal slicing condition we can pursue the gravitational collapse until the radius of the shell decreases to about 0.7 x (the radius of the event horizon). (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: Proof of a multipole conjecture due to Geroch

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONFORMAL MAPPING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MULTIPOLES; POTENTIAL ENERGY; RIEMANN SPACE; SMOOTH MANIFOLDS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A result, first conjectured by Geroch, is proved to the extent, that the multipole moments of a static space-time characterize this space-time uniquely. As an offshoot of the proof one obtains an essentially coordinate-free algorithm for explicitly writing down a geometry in terms of it's moments in a purely algebraic manner. This algorithm seems suited for symbolic manipulation on a computer. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Kay, B.S. (Princeton Univ., NJ (USA). Inst. for Advanced Study; Imperial Coll. of Science and Technology, London (UK). Blackett Lab.; Bern Univ. (Switzerland). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: In-out semi-classical gravity and 1/N quantum gravity

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FEYNMAN DIAGRAM; MATRIX ELEMENTS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIAGRAMS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INFORMATION; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Classical gravity with higher derivatives, when coupled to the in-out matrix element of Tsub(μ)sub(ν): (a) appears to be free from instabilities of the in-in theory; (b) may be considered as the underlying classical theory to Tomboulis' 1/N-resummed quantum gravity. I explain how these two facts may be adduced as evidence for the viability both of the former semi-classical approximation and of the latter approach to full quantum gravity. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Kodama, Hideo (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Conserved energy flux for the spherically symmetric system and the backreaction problem in the black hole evaporation

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 63(4) p. 1217-1228; ISSN 0033-068X; Apr 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EVAPORATION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; RADIATION FLUX; SINGULARITY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For the spherically symmetric system, we prove the existence of a new locally conserved flux which can be interpreted to represent the total energy flux of matter and gravitational field. With the aid of this conservation law, we study the relation between the behavior of the event horizon and the energy flux across it and look for constraints imposed on the total energy radiated to infinity. Some implications of the results of this study to the backreaction problem in the black hole evaporation are discussed. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The algorithms are studied which construct stationary axisymmetric asymptotically flat spacetimes. The multipole moment structure of the resulting spacetimes is determined. The static metric and the transformations which generate any stationary metric are obtained

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Hiscock, W.A. (Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut 06520)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Models of evaporating black holes. I

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(12) p. 2813-2822; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jun 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EVAPORATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCALAR FIELDS; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Classical spacetimes which contain evaporating black holes (EBH's) are constructed using the Vaidya metric. These model EBH spacetimes are spherically symmetric, asymptotically flat, and contain event horizons which terminate after finite duration. These model EBH spacetimes are then used as fixed backgrounds for particle-creation calculations, in an attempt to learn something of the dynamics of real, semiclassical EBH spacetimes while bypassing the difficulties associated with the back-reaction problem. The stress-energy tensor of a quantized massless scalar field is studied on the two-dimensional EBH spacetimes obtained by setting dtheta = dphi = 0. If lim(dM/dv)not =0 as M→0 (v the usual ingoing null coordinate), then an infinite flux of outgoing radiation is produced along the Cauchy horizon of the EBH. This behavior suggests that a correct, self-consistent semiclassical EBH spacetime must have lim(dM/dv) = 0 as M→0, contrary to the behavior deduced by naively extrapolating Hawking's result all the way down to M = 0, which gives dM/dvapprox.M-2. It also shows that not all zero-mass naked singularities left at the end point of an evaporating black hole are benign; they may produce a divergent flux of created particles

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Papadopoulos, D.; Stewart, B.; Witten, L. (Department of Physics, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, Ohio 45221)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Some properties of a particular static, axially symmetric space-time

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 24(2) p. 320-326; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The behavior of the directional singularities of a family of Weyl solutions is examined. By examining the space-time in a different coordinate system, the directional singularities are understood. The singular points are actually extended hypersurfaces which have been collapsed to a point by an improper choice of coordinates. The singular structure is examined in the new coordinate system. The coordinate system shows the space-time to be geodesically incomplete. A completion of the symmetry axis is described

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Barger, V.; Whisnant, K.; Phillips, R.J.N. (Physics Department, University of Wisconsin: Madison, Madison, Wisconsin 53706)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Realistic calculations of solar-neutrino oscillations

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 24(2) p. 538-541; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We reexamine the possible effects of oscillations on the apparent solar-neutrino flux, integrated over the theoretical solar spectrum weighted by the 37Cl or 71Ga neutrino capture cross section. Spectral, thermal, and distance averaging do not reduce all oscillations to their mean values. The averaged ν/sub e/→ν/sub e/ transition probability can fall as low as 0.1. Annual variations are evaluated

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Integrability formulation and Baecklund transformations for gravitational fields with symmetries

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCHROEDINGER EQUATION; SO GROUPS; SU-2 GROUPS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Ernst equation for gravitational fields with a two-parameter isometry group is formulated as a vanishing-curvature condition on an SU(2) or SU(1,1) bundle, both in the elliptic and hyperbolic cases. Baecklund transformations are introduced as a special case of gauge transformations, and strong Baecklund transformations are obtained in that context

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Kleber, A. (Observatorio Nacional, Rio de Janeiro (Brazil)); Fonseca Teixeira, A.F. da (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational peculiarities of a scalar field

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; METRICS; ORBITS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; THEORETICAL DATA

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DATA; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The zero-adjoint of a time-static Ricci-flat solution to Einstein's field equations is investigated. It represents a spacetime curved solely by a massless scalar field. The cylindrical symmetry is assumed to permit both planar and non-planar geodetic motions. Unusual, velocity-dependent gravitational features are encountered from these geodesics. (Author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1979

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Hu, B.L. (Maryland Univ., College Park (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Effect of the finite-temperature quantum fields on the early universe

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The finite-temperature effect of a quantized conformally invariant scalar field in a closed Robertson-Walker universe is studied. The general solution is characterized by one parameter xi = Ta which measures the radiation content of the universe. In the high-temperature limit it reduces to the Fischetti-Hartle-Hu solution where the universe expands linearly in cosmic time near the singularity. In the low-temperature limit, it reduces to a Starobinsky-de Sitter type solution where the singularity is avoided in an exponential expansion. Several characteristic functional dependences of γ(t) are used to illustrate possible entropy generating processes. The finite-temperature formalism thus provides a unifying framework for the description of the interplay of vacuum and radiation energy and their combined effect on the state of the early universe. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Schendel, J.; Winicour, J. (Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15260)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Restrictions on relativistically rotating fluids

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; QUASARS; RED SHIFT; ROTATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We develop an extensive set of inequalities which apply to the surface of a relativistically rotating fluid with asymptotically flat exterior. We explore the physical content of these inequalities by examining the restrictions they impose on the existence of rotating fluid models with Kerr exteriors. In that case, the dominant set of inequalities can be expressed in a simple analytic form. We find for all models with Kerr parameter a>m that there is a finite maximum redshift between observers at the fluid surface and at infinity. However, for all models with 0<a/m< or =1 there is no upper bound to the redshift. In the static limit, as a/m→0, a finite redshift maximum emerges in a discontinuous manner. The value of this maximum depends upon the moment of inertia of the static background fluid. We discuss the implications toward the possibility of a high redshift quasar model

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The multipole expansion in general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Acta Physica Austriaca; v. 53(4) p. 249-270; ISSN 0001-6713; 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; MULTIPOLES; SPACE-TIME; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A recently undertaken study of multipole moments in General Relativity is completed and different approaches summarized in a unified manner. Among the new results in this paper is a treatment of the behaviour of the multipole moments under finite translations and generalizations of the notion of a centre of mass (charge) to the case, when the mass is zero. Furthermore the author studies the dependence of the multipoles on the choice of the potential. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Quantum effects in cosmological models with singularities

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DE SITTER GROUP; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPECTATION VALUE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; RENORMALIZATION; SCALAR FIELDS; SINGULARITY; SPINOR FIELDS; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Accurate calculation of vacuum averages of energy-pulse tensor of quantum scalar and spin fields in de Sitter space of the first kind, is conducted by the regularization method. Limiting cases of the obtained accurate expressions are considered. It is noted, that space of the Sitter is a self-agreeable solution of Einstein equation with account of quantum fluctuations of vacuum of non-massive fields

meta.content: The trace anomaly in coloured black holes

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BAG MODEL; BLACK HOLES; COLOR MODEL; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MAGNETIC FIELDS; METRICS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; YANG-MILLS THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COMPOSITE MODELS; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUARK MODEL

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The influence of the trace anomaly of the energy-momentum tensor of gauge theories is discussed in a spherically symmetric space-time. It is found that for pure electric and magnetic fields, the point β(g) = -g represents a phase transition from an asymptotically flat metric to an asymptotically non-flat metric which turns out to be confining in the electric case. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Regular minimum of the scale factor of co-moving space in general relativity theory

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Regulyarnyj minimum masshtabnogo faktora soputstvuyushchego prostranstva v teorii tyagoteniya Ejnshtejna

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Vestnik Moskovskogo Universiteta, Seriya 3. Fizika, Astronomiya; v. 22(3) p. 49-54; ISSN 0579-9392; Mar - Apr 1981; For English translation see the journal Moscow University Physics Bulletin (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Existence of an analytical solution of the Einstein equation containing the maximum number of physically arbitrary functions, in which the R scale factor of co-moving space passes through the regular minimum corresponding to the finite density, is shown. The cases of ideal and viscous medium under conditions of full assignment of the law of viscosity are considered. Near the regular R minimum the character of deformation of co-moving space, volume and density variations of ideal and viscous medium are considered

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Semenzato, R.; Ipser, J.R. (The University of Chicago)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Odd-parity pertubations of spherically symmetric star clusters in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Astrophysical Journal; v. 247(2) p. 671-676; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Jul 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: DISTURBANCES; EIGENFREQUENCY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; INSTABILITY; OSCILLATION MODES; PARITY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; STAR CLUSTERS; SYMMETRY; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTICLE PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The theory of odd-parity nonspherical peturbations of collisionless, isotropic, spherically symmetric star clusters is developed within general relativity for l> or =2. A variational principle is derived for the associated normal modes of oscillation. The variational expression reveals that an unstable normal mode has a pure exponentially growing time dependence--the corresponding complex ''eigenfrequency'' is purely imaginary--and hence that a normal mode can become unstable in a smooth fashion only thorugh zero frequency. Further, it is shown that no instabilities can set in through zero-frequency modes along smooth sequences of models with fewer high-energy stars than low-energy stars. Unless unstable normal modes suddenly appear in a nonsmooth fashion, the implications is that these models possess no unstable normal modes

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Ikeda, S. (Science Univ. of Tokyo, Noda, Chiba (Japan). Faculty of Science and Technology)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Some physico-geometrical remarks on the relationship between the micro- and macro-gravitational fields

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 25(1) p. 21-25; ISSN 0024-1318; 5 May 1979

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICS; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Under the premise that the micro-gravitational field has a Finslerian structure due to the space-time fluctuation (xi), some ''non''-Riemannian features underlying the macro-gravitational field are investigated. And the averaging process with respect to xi is reconsidered from the standpoint of geometrical thermodynamics. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear

Faculty of Science and Technology</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:13669712</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Lettere al Nuovo Cimento</title> <title type="abbreviated">Lett. Nuovo Cim</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0024-1318</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 25(1) p. 21-25.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05908" assignment="indexer">mathematics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09910" assignment="indexer">tensors</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Under the premise that the micro-gravitational field has a Finslerian structure due to the space-time fluctuation (xi), some ''non''-Riemannian features underlying the macro-gravitational field are investigated. And the averaging process with respect to xi is reconsidered from the standpoint of geometrical thermodynamics. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="IT">Italy</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Goode, S.W.; Wainwright, J. (Waterloo Univ., Ontario (Canada). Dept. of Applied Mathematics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Friedmann-like singularities in Szekeres' cosmological models

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society; v. 198(1) p. 83-90; ISSN 0035-8711; Jan 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SINGULARITY; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The existence is established of Friedmann-like singularities in a subclass of the Szekeres cosmological models which admits no Killing vector fields, and which depends on three arbitrary functions of a single variable. The asymptotic properties of the solutions are described as the singularity is approached, for example the behaviour of the matter density, the rate of shear of the matter, and the Weyl conformal curvature tensor. The solutions are formulated in a way which permits comparison with linear perturbations of the Einstein-de Sitter solution. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: DEI

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The spatially averaged semi-classical Gowdy T3 cosmological model is constructed and evolved self-consistently. It is shown that quantum effects replace the classically present singularity with a symmetric bounce. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.content: Gravitational quadrupole formulae and gravitationally bound matter systems

meta.content: Journal article

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For gravitationally bound matter systems, a new approach to the gravitational quadrupole radiation problem is presented. It simultaneously gives the energy loss rate at infinity and the radiation-reaction force on the matter system, without using singular asymptotic expansions and without encountering long-range divergences. The quadrupole formulae are confirmed

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: There is a wide range of fundamental physical problems directly related to how pulsars function. Some of these are independent of the specific pulsar mechanism. Others relate directly to the physics of the pulsar and already shed some light on the properties of matter at high density (approx.1015 g/cc) and in strong magnetic fields (approx.1012 G). Pulsars are assumed to be rotating neutron stars surrounded by strong magnetic fields and energetic particles. It is somewhere within this ''magnetosphere'' that the pulsar action is expected to take place. Currently there has been considerable difficulty in formulating an entirely self-consistent theory of the magnetospheric behavior and there may be rapid revisions in the near future, which is all the more surprising since many of the issues involve ''elementary'' problems in electromagnetism. One interesting discovery is that charge-separated plasmas apparently can support stable static discontinuities

atmospheres</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12363" assignment="upposted">timing properties</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">There is a wide range of fundamental physical problems directly related to how pulsars function. Some of these are independent of the specific pulsar mechanism. Others relate directly to the physics of the pulsar and already shed some light on the properties of matter at high density (approx.10<sup>15</sup> g/cc) and in strong magnetic fields (approx.10<sup>12</sup> G). Pulsars are assumed to be rotating neutron stars surrounded by strong magnetic fields and energetic particles. It is somewhere within this ''magnetosphere'' that the pulsar action is expected to take place. Currently there has been considerable difficulty in formulating an entirely self-consistent theory of the magnetospheric behavior and there may be rapid revisions in the near future, which is all the more surprising since many of the issues involve ''elementary'' problems in electromagnetism. One interesting discovery is that charge-separated plasmas apparently can support stable static discontinuities</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Howes, R.J. (La Trobe Univ., Bundoora (Australia). Dept. of Mathematics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Effects of a positive cosmological constant on circular orbits in the Reissner-Nordstroem, Schwarzschild, and Kerr fields

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 13(9) p. 829-835; ISSN 0001-7701; Sep 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CIRCULAR CONFIGURATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GEODESICS; KERR FIELD; ORBIT STABILITY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS; STABILITY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Criteria for the existence and stability of circular orbits in a general stationary axisymmetric field are established using the equation of geodesic deviation. Circular orbits in the Reissner-Nordstrom, Schwarzschild and Kerr fields, all with a positive cosmological constant Λ included, are considered and the effects of Λ are detailed. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Unwin, S.D. (Newcastle upon Tyne Univ. (UK). Dept. of Theoretical Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Twisted symmetry breaking on the projective hypersphere: a model of the small cosmological constant

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(3) p. 841-848; ISSN 0305-4470; Mar 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GOLDSTONE BOSONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY BREAKING; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BOSONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POSTULATED PARTICLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A model is considered in which the gravitational action effectively depends upon the symmetry-broken vacuum state associated with a twisted scalar field theory. It is suggested that the observation of a small cosmological constant, despite predicted vacuum contributions typically of the order 10-6 cm-2, is a consequence of our location in the universe. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The behavior of null geodesics in a class of rotating space-time homogeneous cosmologies

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 13(11) p. 1093-1115; ISSN 0001-7701; Nov 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CAUSALITY; COORDINATES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; GLOBAL ANALYSIS; MATTER; ROTATION; SHEAR; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The null geodesics are investigated in a class of open space-time homogeneous cosmological models with rotating sheared matter (Ozsvath class III). Goedel's model is a special case. A stationary polar coordinate system is employed in which matter rotates rigidly. The geodesic equations are solved. Caustics and global rotation are discussed. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Maiti, S.R. (Department of Physics, Presidency College, Calcutta-700073, India)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Fluid with heat flux in a conformally flat space-time

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 25(10) p. 2518-2520; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 May 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HEAT FLUX; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper presents a solution of Einstein's equation in a conformally flat and spherically symmetric space-time with perfect fluid and heat flux as sources when vorticity and shear vanish. With a certain choice of parameters the solution may represent an earlier stage of the Robertson-Walker model. Though acceleration remains, a singularity cannot be avoided in some cases. The horizon of the model cannot be definitely known, but for a particular case it can be assigned. Other behaviors of the solution are similar to those of the Robertson-Walker metric

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.content: Time-dependent, Bianchi II, rotating universe

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; ROTATION; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An exact cosmological solution of Einstein's equations which has time-dependent rotation is presented. The t-constant sections are of Bianchi type II. The source of this geometry is a fluid which has not been thermalized. (Author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; P INVARIANCE; POLARIZATION; WAVE PROPAGATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Equations of a weak gravitational field are studied without usual simplificatttions. The aention is paid to the difference of gravitational waves from electromagnetic. It is shown that the weak gravitational waves, along with the polarization possess the orientation. Two P symmetrical sources radiate waves of opposite orientations; this suggests the possibility of unusuat interference effects

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Marathe, K.B. (Brooklyn Coll., NY (USA). Dept. of Mathematics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The mean curvature of gravitational fields

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physica A; v. 114(1-3) p. 143-145; ISSN 0378-4371; Aug 1982; 10. International colloquium on group theoretical methods in physics; Canterbury (UK); 31 Aug - 4 Sep 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIFFERENTIAL TOPOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; SPACE; TOPOLOGY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The mean curvature of a gravitational field is defined as a generalization of the average curvature in a given direction by using the gravitational sectional curvature function on non-degenerate tangent 2-planes to the space-time manifold. We find that the mean curvature of a gravitational field is independent of direction as determined by a unit vector. The converse of this result provides a new characterization of spaces admitting gravitational fields. We also define the average curvature (or bending) of a non-degenerate k-plane in a gravitational field and shwo that it is independent of the choice of non-degenerated k-plane. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

assignment="indexer">mathematical manifolds</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08554" assignment="indexer">riemann space</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05907" assignment="upposted">mathematical space</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05908" assignment="upposted">mathematics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10345" assignment="upposted">topology</descriptor> </descriptors> <qualifiers> <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier> </qualifiers> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The mean curvature of a gravitational field is defined as a generalization of the average curvature in a given direction by using the gravitational sectional curvature function on non-degenerate tangent 2-planes to the space-time manifold. We find that the mean curvature of a gravitational field is independent of direction as determined by a unit vector. The converse of this result provides a new characterization of spaces admitting gravitational fields. We also define the average curvature (or bending) of a non-degenerate k-plane in a gravitational field and shwo that it is independent of the choice of non-degenerated k-plane. (orig.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="NL">Netherlands</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A generalisation of the Buchdahl transformation and perfect fluid solutions

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(6) p. 1799-1805; ISSN 0305-4470; Jun 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CANONICAL TRANSFORMATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Perfect fluid solutions in general relativity are examined. The pressure isotropy relation possesses a discrete symmetry in the derivatives of the metric functions. It is shown that a generalisation of Buchdahl's original transformation (Aust. J. Phys.; 9: 13 (1956)) allows new physically reasonable solutions to be obtained from known solutions. An example is given. Previously noticed first by Buchdahl, and later by Glass and Goldman (J. Math. Phys.; 19: 856 (1978)), this symmetry was thought to lead only to unphysical solutions. (author)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Spyrou, N. (Thessaloniki Univ. (Greece). Dept. of Astronomy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Reversible transformations of shapes and sizes of uncharged ergospheres

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(6) p. 1979-1986; ISSN 0305-4470; Jun 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CANONICAL TRANSFORMATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; KERR FIELD; KERR METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The shape and size of a Kerr ergosphere and their reversible transformations are studied systematically. It is proved that due to the ergosphere's total angular momentum, a bulge always forms on its outer boundary either on the axis of rotational symmetry or off it. During the reversible increase of the angular momentum, because of the injection of particles into the ergosphere, the bulge can either approach the symmetry plane or recede from it, while its angular separation from the positive rotation axis increases continuously, approaching the value of 300 for the extreme Kerr ergosphere. The reversible changes of the ergosphere's linear dimensions parallel to the rotation axis and perpendicular to it are studied and the corresponding ranges of their permitted values are specified. (author)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Mielke, E.W. (International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)); Scherzer, R. (Kiel Univ. (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Reine und Angewandte Kernphysik)

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Geon-type solutions of the non-linear Heisenberg-Klein-Gordon equation

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; GLUONS; KLEIN-GORDON EQUATION; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCALAR FIELDS; SOLITONS; SPINORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUASI PARTICLES; WAVE EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: As a model for a ''unitary'' field theory of extended particles we consider the non-linear Klein-Gordon equation - associated with a ''squared'' Heisenberg-Pauli-Weyl non-linear spinor equation - coupled to strong gravity. Using a stationary spherical ansatz for the complex scalar field as well as for the background metric generated via Einstein's field equation, we are able to study the effects of the scalar self-interaction as well as of the classical tensor forces. By numerical integration we obtain a continuous spectrum of localized, gravitational solitons resembling the geons previously constructed for the Einstein-Maxwell system by Wheeler. A self-generated curvature potential originating from the curved background partially confines the Schroedinger type wave functions within the ''scalar geon''. For zero angular momentum states and normalized scalar charge the spectrum for the total gravitational energy of these solitons exhibits a branching with respect to the number of nodes appearing in the radial part of the scalar field. Preliminary studies for higher values of the corresponding ''principal quantum number'' reveal that a kind of fine splitting of the energy levels occurs, which may indicate a rich, particle-like structure of these ''quantized geons''. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author gives a brief account of some progresses which have been made recently on the Cauchy problem in General Relativity, for pure gravitation or gravitation coupled with other fields. The two aspects of this problem are examined: the evolution of initial data; the solution of the constraint equations for the initial data. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Studies on a particular class of asymptotically flat and stationary metric solutions called the Kerr-Tomimatsu-Sato class are reviewed about its derivation and properties. For a further study, an almost complete list of the papers worked on the Tomimatsu-Sato metrics is given. (Auth.)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A cosmological version of flatness conditions in general relativity

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In terms of our cosmological extention of Arnowitt, Deser and Misner's canonical formalism to the Einstein equations, Arnowitt and Deser's flatness conditions in general relativity are reformulated on the simplifying assumption that the cosmological vacuum is represented by the de Sitter universe. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Frenkel, A.; Brecher, K. (Department of Astronomy, Boston University, Boston, Massachusetts 02215)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Horizon-free universe

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 26(2) p. 368-372; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; RICCI TENSOR; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We have studied a theory of gravity, consistent with all astronomical observations, which is an extension of general relativity generated by a gravitational field Lagrangian proportional to R+AR2 (where R is the scalar curvature and A is a new dimensional constant). We find cosmological solutions without a particle horizon for any value of A, compatible with cosmological observations if A is negative and small enough. It is pointed out that while alleviating the problem of the large-scale physical uniformity of the universe, the theory may also alleviate the problem of the development of smaller-scale structures from an initially isotropic state, and possibly the problem of ''hidden mass.''

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The success of the Weinberg-Salam theory has clearly indicated that at least two forces of nature, electromagnetic and weak, can be unified in a single scheme. While there are well-founded hopes that even strong interactions will soon be brought into a unified scheme, there has been no tangible success towards the inclusion of gravity. The author therefore adopts a different point of view, i.e., a phenomenological approach towards the unification problem. The results of an extensive analysis are presented that show that a large body of data from astronomy, astrophysics, cosmology, geophysics and paleontology, are compatible with a scheme in which all the forces were of the same strength in the early phases of the Big Bang. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On a covariant 2+2 formulation of the initial value problem in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Mar 1980; 146 p; ; Available from British Library, Boston Spa, Wetherby, West Yorks. No. D35862/81; Thesis (Ph.D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS; CAUCHY PROBLEM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; SPACE-TIME; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The initial value problems in general relativity are considered from a geometrical standpoint with especial reference to the development of a covariant 2+2 formalism in which space-time is foliated by space-like 2-surfaces under the headings; the Cauchy problem in general relativity, the covariant 3+1 formulation of the Cauchy problem, characteristic and mixed initial value problems, on locally imbedding a family of null hypersurfaces, the 2+2 formalism, the 2+2 formulation of the Cauchy problem, the 2+2 formulation of the characteristic and mixed initial value problems, and a covariant Lagrangian 2+2 formulation. (U.K.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Structure of twistor and H-spaces

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1979; 74 p; ; University Microfilms Order No. 80-14,783; Thesis (Ph. D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; SPINORS; TWISTOR THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In chapter one, we review briefly the spinor and twistor formalisms in general relativity. Following some suggestions of A.H. Taub, we show that the local twistor structure of a general curved space-time is closely related to the conformal structure used by B.G. Schmidt to define conformal infinity. In particular, we prove that the normal Cartan connection of the conformal bundle coincides with the connection which gives the covariant derivative of local twistors. In chapter two, we use the results of E.T. Newman and J. Plebanski to construct some explicit self-dual metrics. These solutions are of interest because they are good candidates for what we would like to call asymptotically flat H-spaces. Furthermore, by a closer look at these metrics, we may gain more insight into the behavior of twistor spaces near the boundary. In chapter three, we study the geometric structure of twistor spaces associated with asymptotically flat space-times. We show that the space of asymptotic projective twistors, PT+, is an Einstein Kaehler manifold of constant holomorphic sectional curvature. We also give a brief description of the twistor space construction of the metrics in chapter two. In chapter four, we apply the Chern-Moser theory of the pseudoconformal geometry of real hypersurfaces in complex manifolds to study the structure of the boundary PN of PT+. Using some ideas due to S. Webster, we show that the Chern-Moser curvature invariants of PN coincide with the Kaehler curvature invariants of PT+. From the results of chapter three, we deduce that the pseudoconformal geodesics (chains) of the boundary are nicely behaved

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: s of PN coincide with the Kaehler curvature invariants of PT+. From the results of chapter three, we deduce that the pseudoconformal geodesics (chains) of the boundary are nicely behaved

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: By considering the modification in conservation laws when the gravitational constant G is allowed by via a scale-invariant formalism, we place consistent limits on G/G. If Gproportionalt/sup epsilon-c/, then our ''best'' model has Vertical Barepsilon-cVertical Bar< or approx. =3 x 10-3 and Vertical BarG/GVertical Bar/sub now/approx.Vertical Barepsilont-1/sub now/Vertical Bar< or approx. =1.7 x 10-13 yr-1. These values are comparable to, but approximately a factor of 2 stronger than, limits found in naive models where the conservation laws are not taken into account

meta.content: General relativistic collapse of rotating supermassive stars

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 66(6) p. 2038-2051; ISSN 0033-068X; Dec 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; ROTATION; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; STAR EVOLUTION; SUPERMASSIVE STARS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Numerical calculations have been done for the formation process of axisymmetric, rotating supermassive black holes. Polytropic distribution with N = 3 is used as the initial density distribution. Calculated models are characterized by the total angular momentum (J) and the rotation law. The two types of the initial rotation law are examined. As the effect of rotation is the strongest at the center for the differential rotation law case, the matter distribution becomes disk-like. In this case, if q = (J/M2) <= 0.92 an apparent horizon is formed. If q >= 0.92, the disk-like matter expands toward the lateral direction. For the almost rigidly rotating case, the oblate shape core is always formed because the effect of rotation at the center is not so strong as the former case. In this case if q <= 1.05 an apparent horizon is formed. For large q, for example q = 1.46, the central core bounces and a jet which expands mainly along the rotational axis appears. For the collapse of 109 M sub(solar mass) star, the kinetic energy of the jet becomes 3.6 x 1060 ergs, which is comparable to the total energy stored in the radio lobes of the extragalactic double radio sources. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COMPOSITE MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; SPHERES; STRONG INTERACTIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE MODELS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We show that if the late stages in the nakedly singular collapse of a radiating fluid sphere are treated within the framework of a composite (''bootstrap'') model of strongly interacting particles then the end state need only be instantaneously singular. This is in contrast to the elementary-particle description which does not allow a smooth continuation of the external field onto Minkowski space

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: DEI

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Detailed explanations of the cohomology invoked in the group-manifold approach to supergravity is given. The Chevalley cohomology theory of Lie algebras is extended to graded Lie algebras. The scheme of geometrical theories is enlarged so to include cosmological terms and higher powers of the curvature. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: A cosmological model with compact space sections and low mass density

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; QUASARS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A general relativistic cosmological model is presented which has closed space sections and mass density below a critical density similar to that of Friedmann's models. The model may predict double images of cosmic sources: a hint is made at a qualitative application to quasar astronomy. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that for the complete description of the particle fields at E → infinity it is necessary to introduce bose- and fermi-vacuum fields. It is proved that in the Einstein equations it is necessary to ihtroduce a cosmological term proportional to the square of the bose-vacuum field strength

meta.content: In this paper we show that the contribution to the Bjorken scaling violation, which is due to the gravitational field, disappears at very short distances because of the foam-like structure of the space-time
