meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Gibbons, G.W.; Hawking, S.W. (Cambridge Univ. (UK). Dept. of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics); Horowitz, G.T. (Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, NJ (USA)); Perry, M.J. (Princeton Univ., NJ (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Positive mass theorems for black holes

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 88(3) p. 295-308; ISSN 0010-3616; Mar 1983; CODEN: CMPHA.

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC CHARGES; METRICS; REST MASS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MASS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We extend Witten's proof of the positive mass theorem at spacelike infinity to show that the mass is positive for initial data on an asymptotically flat spatial hypersurface μ which is regular outside an apparent horizon H. In addition, we prove that if a black hole has electromagnetic charge, then the mass is greater than the modulus of the charge. These results are also valid for the Bondi mass at null infinity. Finally, in the case of the Einstein equation with a negative cosmological constant we show that a suitably defined mass is positive for data on an asymptotically anti-de Sitter surface μ which is regular outside an apparent horizon. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Study of a Bianchi type-V cosmological model with torsion

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 26(10) p. 2611-2614; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Nov 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE-TIME; SPIN; TENSORS; TORSION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A Bianchi type-V exact solution of the Einstein-Cartan theory representing several classes of perfect-fluid homogeneous cosmological models is studied. With the introduction of an effective energy-momentum tensor, a dual description of the solution is given within the framework of general relativity, whereby it is shown that the two theories, although formally equivalent, provide physically inequivalent interpretations of the solution. Examined in some detail are the singularity behavior as well as other features of the models

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A survey of applications based either on fundamental algorithms in computer algebra or on the use of a computer algebra system is presented. Recent work in biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics and computer science is discussed. In particular, applications in high energy physics (quantum electrodynamics), celestial mechanics and general relativity are reviewed. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.content: ADJOINT DIFFERENCE METHOD; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HAMILTONIANS; INHOMOGENEOUS FIELDS; SCALAR FIELDS; SINGULARITY; UNIVERSE; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; QUANTUM OPERATORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The ADM-type Hamiltonian formulation of Gowdy S1xS2 and S3 vacuum inhomogeneous cosmological models is given. The canonical and constraint equations are explicitly solved and the asymptotic behaviour of the most general solution in the neighbourhood of the initial and final inhomogeneous scalar singularities is shown to be of the generalised Kasner type. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Ray, J.R.; Mein Sieng Wei (Clemson Univ., S.C. (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A solution-generating theorem with applications in general relativity

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATHEMATICS; MATRICES; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A solution-generating theorem due to Bonnor is generalized and applied to several well-known space-times. The main purpose of the study is to investigate one of the many solution-generating theorems in some detail. The applications lead to a) a static electrovacuum solution which contains both the Reissner-Nordstrom and Robinson-Bertotti solutions as special cases, b) a negative-mass Schwarzschild solution associated with a positive-mass Reissner-Nordstrom solution, c) the Patnaik static electrovacuum solution associated with the Taub plane-symmetry vacuum solution, d) one of the Witten electrovacuum solutions for a charged wire associated with the Weyl-Levi-Civita cylindrically symmetric vacuum solution, e) a stationary electrovacuum solution which contains both a stationary generalization of the Robinson-Bertotti solution and the Kerr-Newman solution as special cases. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1977

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Symmetry breaking in d=11 supergravity on the parallelized seven-sphere

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Phys. Lett., B; v. 122(3/4) p. 225-231; ISSN 0370-2693; 10 Mar 1983; CONTRACT 23681; CODEN: PYLBA.

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOSONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; METRICS; PHOTONS; SO GROUPS; SUPERGRAVITY; SUPERSYMMETRY; SYMMETRY BREAKING; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the vacuum solution proposed by Englert, in which the three-index photon of d=11 supergravity plays the role of a non-vanishing torsion which parallelizes the seven-sphere, all supersymmetries are broken. A bosonic symmetry group SO(3,2)xG2 remains, as anticipated by Englert. These results are derived by constructing Killing vectors in the group manifold. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Two singular quantum universes

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SINGULARITY; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The ADM formalism is used for the quantization of 1) the Bertotti-Robinson universe and 2) Goedel's universe. In the light of the results obtained, the problem of quantum singularities is then discussed. According to certain definitions given, it is seen that in case 1) the classical singularity is not avoided and in 2) a new singularity is created. (author)

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PLASMA

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Electromagnetic effect of a relativistic anisotropic plasma on an intensive plane gravitational wave (GW), is considered. It is shown that the linear electromagnetic effect is possible if the axis of anisotropy does not coincide with the direction of GW propagation, using beam distribution and magneto-active plasma as an example

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Davies, P.C.W. (Newcastle upon Tyne Univ. (UK). Dept of Theoretical Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Inflation and time asymmetry in the Universe

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMMETRY; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is argued that, using the recently proposed inflationary Universe model, a natural explanation is provided for the origin of time asymmetry('time's arrow') in the Universe. In this scenario the temporary dominance of the cosmological term in the gravitational field equation, which acts as a sort of repulsive gravity, generates large quantities of energy and radiation entropy, while drastically reducing the entropy density of the gravitational field. A large gap is thus established between the radiation entropy and the gravitational entropy which gravity is now trying to close. (U.K.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Space-time may have large fluctuations of geometry on short-length scales, which are induced by one-loop quantum-gravitational corrections. Some instanton-like self-consistent solutions have been found, which describe these space-time fluctuations. (orig.)

meta.content: Kinoshita, T.; Lindquist, W.B. (Newman Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, New York 14853)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Eighth-order magnetic moment of the electron. I. Second-order vertex containing second-, fourth-, and sixth-order vacuum polarization subdiagrams

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 27(4) p. 867-876; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Feb 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; VACUUM STATES; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We have calculated the contribution to the eighth-order anomalous magnetic moment of the electron arising from 25 Feynman diagrams generated by inserting second-, fourth-, and sixth-order vacuum polarization loops in the photon line of the second-order vertex diagram. Our result is 0.0766(6)(α/π)4. The theoretical error represents the estimated accuracy (90% confidence limit) of the numerical integrations

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Chernoff, D.F.; Barrow, J.D. (Department of Physics, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Chaos in the mixmaster universe

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review Letters; v. 50(2) p. 134-137; ISSN 0031-9007; 10 Jan 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; MAPS; OSCILLATIONS; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A four-dimensional system of nonlinear difference equations describing the evolution of the general relativistic ''mixmaster'' cosmological model is studied. The evolution splits into two parts: one given by a (chaotic) generalized Baker's transformation and the other by a (systematic) change of scales. The chaotic degrees of freedom are studied in detail: Their evolution may be described by a two-sided shift and the invariant measure for these variables is found. Strong ergodic properties (mixing, nonzero entropy) are deduced

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Gautreau, R. (Physics Department, New Jersey Institute of Technology, Newark, New Jersey 07102)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Geodesic coordinates in the de Sitter universe

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 27(4) p. 764-778; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Feb 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We analyze the de Sitter universe using geodesic clock reference systems. Our starting point is the de Sitter universe described with a static metric form where curvature coordinates are used. This curvature metric form contains a horizon across which timelike and null trajectories cannot be followed. We show how to use new geodesic reference systems that will allow trajectories to be followed across the horizon. These geodesic reference systems are analogs to Eddington-Finkelstein and Kruskal-Novikov coordinate systems that have previously been used to analyze the Schwarzschild field. The resulting comoving synchronous coordinate systems result in metrics for the de Sitter universe that are markedly different in form from the standard Robertson-Walker isotropic metric form. This leads to questions of whether it is valid to describe the de Sitter universe with isotropic Robertson-Walker coordinates

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Gravitational calorons

meta.name: Source

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INSTANTONS; METRICS; STATISTICAL MECHANICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MECHANICS; QUASI PARTICLES; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Finite temperature solutions to euclidean gravity (i.e. with ++++ signature) are constructed on the analogy of the ''caloron'' solutions of the Yang-Mills field. In contrast to the known finite temperature metrics, the imaginary time coordinate (tau) is not a cyclic coordinate here. The metric components are periodic functions of tau. The zero-temperature limit of these solutions gives non-trivial metrics including in particular gravitational instantons corresponding to multicenter metrics of Taub-NUT type. Finite temperature solutions with non self-dual curvature are also found. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Modeling sources of gravitational radiation

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DETECTION; EQUATIONS; ERUPTIVE VARIABLE STARS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; ITERATIVE METHODS; MECHANICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; RADIATIONS; SIMULATION; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A computer code has been developed to aid in the mathematical simulation of violent stellar collisions and collapses expected to generate gravity waves. Numerical methods were used in the code to allow for the calculation of accurate solutions to nonspherical general-relativistic hydrodynamic problems when relativistic effects are strong. This code is a tool that can be used to solve dynamic relativistic problems. In one class of such problems no matter is present. Two examples are the formation of a black hole by gravitational radiation and the interaction of gravitational waves with a black hole. In the class of problems that contain matter, the focus is on cases in which the distribution of matter is nonspherical. Examples are gravitational collapse, oscillation, and formation of black holes. Here the concern is to calculate the production of gravitational radiation from such objects. (SC)

key="08188" assignment="upposted">radiations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11477" assignment="upposted">simulation</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09459" assignment="upposted">stars</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12357" assignment="upposted">variable stars</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A computer code has been developed to aid in the mathematical simulation of violent stellar collisions and collapses expected to generate gravity waves. Numerical methods were used in the code to allow for the calculation of accurate solutions to nonspherical general-relativistic hydrodynamic problems when relativistic effects are strong. This code is a tool that can be used to solve dynamic relativistic problems. In one class of such problems no matter is present. Two examples are the formation of a black hole by gravitational radiation and the interaction of gravitational waves with a black hole. In the class of problems that contain matter, the focus is on cases in which the distribution of matter is nonspherical. Examples are gravitational collapse, oscillation, and formation of black holes. Here the concern is to calculate the production of gravitational radiation from such objects. (SC)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We develop an O(5) gauge theory in which the O(5) symmetry is spontaneously broken to O(4) with a scale on the order of the Planck mass. The ten components of the O(5) gauge field are identified as the four vierbeins and six connections of Euclidean general relativity. In the strong-coupling limit the effective action is dominated by a dimension-five operator induced by the anomalous fermion triangle loop which turns out to be the usual Hilbert action. The metric is not a dynamical field in this model and its equation of constraint is just the usual metric-vierbein relation. We suggest SU(9)containsSU(5) x O(5) as the simplest group for a totally unified theory

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The limits of validity of the semiclassical theory in which gravity is unquantized are discussed. This is done by comparing the emission of classical gravitational waves in the semiclassical theory with graviton emission in quantum gravity theory. It is shown that these can be quite different even for macroscopic systems. thus quantum gravitational effects can manifest themselves on a macroscopic scale. a hypothetical experiment to demonstrate the existence of gravitons by means of such effects is discussed

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.content: Proper-time gauge in the quantum theory of gravitation

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source

meta.name: RecordType

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FEYNMAN PATH INTEGRAL; GAUGE INVARIANCE; HAMILTONIANS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; TIME DEPENDENCE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM OPERATORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The proper-time gauge appears to be the simplest one consistent with the invariance properties of the gravitational action. It also permits one to implement in a direct manner the requirement of causality in the quantum theory of gravitation. In this paper the measure for the path integral over gravitational fields in the proper-time gauge is explicitly worked out. The corresponding propagation amplitude results after the following steps: (i) evaluating the amplitude for a transition between two three-geometries for which one specifies the relative pointwise proper-time separation and relative spatial coordinate system, (ii) integrating over all positive proper-time separations with a logarithmic measure, (iii) averaging over all possible choices of the relative coordinate system. (An explicit expression for the measure over the diffeomorphism group in terms of a set of ghost fields emerges from the path integral.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATTER; METRICS; MOTION; OSCILLATIONS; SPHERES; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The line element given by McVittie (Ann. Inst. H. Poincare, A VI, 1 (1967)) for a spherically symmetric distribution of matter is generalized. Conditions which are necessary and sufficient are given for the density to be uniform. The motion of the matter configuration is investigated with a view to oscillations using different physical conditions and initial conditions. It is shown that for many classes of solutions, these conditions are sufficient to conclude that oscillations are not possible. Particularly it is found that for a gaseous mass, oscillations are not possible. For other classes of solutions, it is shown that the conditions necessary for the solutions to be physically acceptable, are consistent with oscillations. However, these conditions are in general not sufficient. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Reboucas, M.J.; Tiomno, J.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On the homogeneity of Riemannian space-times of Goedel type

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The conditions for space-time homogeneity of a Riemannian manifold with a Godel-type metric are examined. The Raychaudhuri-Thakurta necessary conditions are shown to be also sufficient and to lead to five linearly independent Killing vectors. These vector fields are exhibited for the most general case and their algebra are examined. The irreducible set of isometrically independent ST-homogeneous Godel-type metrics is shown to be given, in cylindrical coordinates, by ds2 = [dt + 4Ω/m2 sinh2 (mr)/2) d phi]2 - 1/m2 sinh2 (mr) d phi2 - dr2 - dz2, where Ω is the vorticity and - infinity < = m2 < = + infinity, m2 = 2Ω2 corresponding to the Godel metric. Sources of Einstein equations leading to these metrics as solutions are examined and it is shown that the inclusion of a scalar field extends the previously known region of solutions - infinity < = m2 < = 2Ω2 to - infinity < = m2 < = 4Ω2. The problem of ambiguity of physical sources of the same metric and that of violation of causality in Godel-type ST-homogeneous universes are examined. In the case m2 = 4Ω2 the first exact Godel-type solution of Einstein equations describing a completely causal ST-homogeneous rotating universe is obtained. (Author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

</titles> <date value="1982--" sici-chronology="1982">1982</date> <physical-description>42 p.</physical-description> <country key="BR">Brazil</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Reboucas, M.J.</creator> <creator type="personal">Tiomno, J.</creator> <creator type="corporate">Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro</creator> </creators> type="valid" key="02278" assignment="indexer">cosmology</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" assignment="indexer">scalar fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05907" assignment="upposted">mathematical space</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The conditions for space-time homogeneity of a Riemannian manifold with a Godel-type metric are examined. The Raychaudhuri-Thakurta necessary conditions are shown to be also sufficient and to lead to five linearly independent Killing vectors. These vector fields are exhibited for the most general case and their algebra are examined. The irreducible set of isometrically independent ST-homogeneous Godel-type metrics is shown to be given, in cylindrical coordinates, by ds<sup>2</sup> = [dt + 4Ω/m<sup>2</sup> sinh<sup>2</sup> (mr)/2) d phi]<sup>2</sup> - 1/m<sup>2</sup> sinh<sup>2</sup> (mr) d phi<sup>2</sup> - dr<sup>2</sup> - dz<sup>2</sup>, where Ω is the vorticity and - infinity < = m<sup>2</sup> < = + infinity, m<sup>2</sup> = 2Ω<sup>2</sup> corresponding to the Godel metric. Sources of Einstein equations leading to these metrics as solutions are examined and it is shown that the inclusion of a scalar field extends the previously known region of solutions - infinity < = m<sup>2</sup> < = 2Ω<sup>2</sup> to - infinity < = m<sup>2</sup> < = 4Ω<sup>2</sup>. The problem of ambiguity of physical sources of the same metric and that of violation of causality in Godel-type ST-homogeneous universes are examined. In the case m<sup>2</sup> = 4Ω<sup>2</sup> the first exact Godel-type solution of Einstein equations describing a completely causal ST-homogeneous rotating universe is obtained. (Author)</abstract> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="pt">Examinam-se as condicoes para a homogeneidade de uma variedade Riemanniana com uma metrica do tipo Godel. Mostra-se que as condicoes necessarias de Raychaudhiri-Thakurta sao tambem suficientes e levam a cinco vetores de Killing linearmente independentes. Exibem-se esses campos vetoriais para o caso mais geral e examinam-se suas algebras. Mostra-se que o conjunto irredutivel de metricas do tipo Godel ST-homogeneo isometricamente independente e dado, em coordenadas cilindricas, por ds<sup>2</sup> = [dt + 4Ω/m<sup>2</sup> senh<sup>2</sup> (mr/2) d phi]<sup>2</sup> - 1/m<sup>2</sup> senh<sup>2</sup> (mr) d phi<sup>2</sup> - dr<sup>2</sup> - dz<sup>2</sup>, onde Ω e a vorticidade e - infinito < = m<sup>2</sup> < = + infinito, m<sup>2</sup> = 2Ω<sup>2</sup> correspondendo a metrica de Godel. Examinam-se as fontes da sequacoes de Einstein que tem essas metricas como solucoes e mostra-se que a inclusao de um campo escalar extende a regiao previamente conhecida de solucoes - infinito < = m<sup>2</sup> < = 2Ω<sup>2</sup> para - infinito < = m<sup>2</sup> < = 4Ω<sup>2</sup>. Examinam-se os problemas de ambiguidades de fontes fisicas da mesma metrica e da violacao de causalidade em universos ST-homogeneos do tipo Godel. Obtem-se no caso m<sup>2</sup> = 4Ω<sup>2</sup> a primeira solucao do tipo Godel exata das equacoes de Einstein descrevendo universo girante ST-homogeneo completamente causal. (L.C.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="BR">Brazil</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Exact cosmological solutions of Einstein-Maxwell equations as perturbations of the Bertotti-Robinson model

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; HYDRODYNAMICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Two new classes of spatially homogeneous cosmological solutions of Einstein-Maxwell equations are obtained by considering a class of exact perturbations of the static Bertotti-Robinson (BR) model. The BR solution is shown to be unstable under these perturbations, being perturbed into exact cosmological solutions with perfect fluid (equations of state p = lambda rho, O < = lambda < = 1), isotropic/anisotropic expansion and non-null electric conductivity. (Author)

meta.content: January 1985

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The theory of electro-weak interactions and Jordan's description of Einstein's Theory of gravity are unified in a unique scheme. A short-range counterpart of gravity, envolving massive tensor bosons of masses 365 GeV and 520,3 GeV, is obtained within the new scheme. (Author)

meta.content: January 1985

meta.content: Effective Einsteinian gravity from Poincare gauge field theory

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; POINCARE GROUPS; RICCI TENSOR; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Poincare gauge theory of gravity should apply in the microphysical domain. Here we investigate its implications for macrophysics. Weakly self double dual Riemann-Cartan curvature is assumed throughout. It is shown that the metrical background is then determined by Einstein's field equations with the Belinfante-Rosenfeld symmetrized energy-momentum current amended by spin squared terms. Moreover, the effective cosmological constant can be reconciled with the empirical data by absorbing the corresponding constant curvature part into the dynamical torsion of recently found exact solutions. Macroscopically this extra torsion remains undetectable. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1985

meta.content: Hadamard function, stress tensor, and de Sitter space

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(8) p. 2286-2291; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Oct 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MASS; O GROUPS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RENORMALIZATION; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DYNAMICAL GROUPS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Using the ''Hadamard'' formalism, we derive the general expression of the renormalized vacuum expectation value of the stress tensor of a massive scalar field. We apply this formalism to the O(1,4)- and E(3)-invariant vacua of de Sitter space

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Reboucas, M.J.; Teixeira, A.F.F. (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, 22290 Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Features of a relativistic space-time with seven isometries

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(10) p. 2985-2989; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Nov 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CAUSALITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; METRICS; RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE-TIME; SPIN

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTICLE PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Previous works on Reboucas-Tiomno (RT) space-time are extended. We show that the RT model is Petrov type 0 and exhibit its conformally flat form. The geodesic equations are fully integrated and the corresponding motions are discussed at length. A comparison with other rare solutions possessing seven isometries is made

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The consistency of the S7 truncation in d=11 supergravity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Nuclear Physics. B; v. 281(1/2) p. 211-240; ISSN 0550-3213; CODEN NUPBB; 19 Jan 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOSONS; COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPINOR FIELDS; SUPERGRAVITY; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; TRANSFORMATIONS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We give a complete proof that d=11 supergravity compactified on S7 admits a consistent truncation to its zero-mass sector. The resulting theory is shown to coincide with gauged N=8 supergravity to all orders. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: Ernst, F.J. (Illinois Inst. of Tech., Chicago (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Applications of the Riemann-Hilbert problem to general relativity

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 21-28; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; INTEGRAL EQUATIONS; POTENTIALS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author outlines the basic ideas involved in the Hauser-Ernst Homogeneous Hilbert Problem (HHP) formulation of the Kinnersley-Chitre transformation theory and the proof of the famous Geroch conjecture that essentially all stationary axially symmetric vacuum solutions may be generated through the action of a group of transformations upon any given known solution such as Minkowski space. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Hu Ning (Peking University, China)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The gravitational radiation damping and the change of coordinates

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 41-50; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BINARY STARS; COORDINATES; DAMPING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS; STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the general theory of relativity, the gravitational waves having temporal and longitudinal components of polarization carry no energy and thus represent only the spurious effect of the coordinates. An expression for the radiation damping force on binary stars is obtained from the field equation by requiring that the out-going gravitational radiation should have only transverse components of polarization. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Alexander, M.; Bergmann, P.G. (Syracuse Univ., NY (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Space-like infinity

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 575-582; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CAUCHY PROBLEM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The authors call attention to the very remarkable independence of the degrees of freedom of the gravitational field at space-like infinity (spi) from those at finite regions of space-time. They succeed in formulating a complete Cauchy problem at spi, with no reference to the remainder of space-time, with all the normal attributes of a dynamical and causal system. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

</descriptors> <qualifiers> <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier> </qualifiers> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The authors call attention to the very remarkable independence of the degrees of freedom of the gravitational field at space-like infinity (spi) from those at finite regions of space-time. They succeed in formulating a complete Cauchy problem at spi, with no reference to the remainder of space-time, with all the normal attributes of a dynamical and causal system. (Auth.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="NL">Netherlands</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Duan Yishi (Lanzhou University, China); Wang Youtang (Shanghai Jiaotong University, China)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The conservation law of energy-momentum in general relativity

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 981-988; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Using the Noether's theorem, a satisfactory conservation law of energy-momentum in general relativity has been obtained from the generalized translational transformation proposed. The reasonableness of this conservation law has been discussed in detail, according to the covariant property of the energy-momentum tensor, total energy of the static system and the radiational problems. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The geometrical interpretation of the Ernst equation as a harmonic problem is briefly reviewed. It is suggested how some results from harmonic maps theory can enlighten the structure of the 'space of solutions' of the Ernst equation. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The metric is presented in terms of six determinants of degree N, in a concise closed form, describing collinear N isolated Kerr masses (N=1,2,3,...) balanced by their gravitational spin-spin interaction. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Kihara, Masahiro; Tomimatsu, Akira (Hiroshima Univ., Takehara (Japan). Research Inst. for Theoretical Physics); Oohara, Ken-ichi (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Dept. of Physics); Sato, Humitaka (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Fundamental Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Structure of the two Kerr-solution

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1049-1052; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Several methods to derive stationary axisymmetric solutions of the Einstein vacuum equation have been developed. One such method is the Baecklund transformation found by Neugebauer. Applying two successive transformations to the flat spacetime, the Kerr-NUT solution is derived. Likewise, the four successive transformation derives an interesting solution, which represents the gravity of the two Kerr particles aligned along their rotation axis. The authors review what has been checked about the properties of this solution. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

One such method is the Baecklund transformation found by Neugebauer. Applying two successive transformations to the flat spacetime, the Kerr-NUT solution is derived. Likewise, the four successive transformation derives an interesting solution, which represents the gravity of the two Kerr particles aligned along their rotation axis. The authors review what has been checked about the properties of this solution. meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We verify by an explicit perturbative calculation arguments presented recently concerning the existence of compactified solutions of superstring theory in which the spin connection is not embedded in the gauge group in the standard way but the gauge connection is a connection on a more general holomorphic vector bundle over a manifold of SU(3) holonomy. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A class of McVittie's new nonquadratic solutions is investigated in some detail with regard to its physical properties. It is found that decreasing pressure and density are not compatible with center regularity for these perfect fluid spheres. It is further seen that for ''gaseous'' spheres (i.e., the density /rho/ drops to zero at the outer boundary of the sphere together with the pressure /rho/) oscillatory motions are not possible. For these ''gaseous'' models the pressure and the density are both positive inside the outer surface, and their respective gradients are negative. For the outer ''gaseous'' shells models are constructed where for a certain time interval the pressure is increasing for contracting models. Without any restriction with respect to time, for these shell models it found that the density is increasing for contracting models, and the adiabatic speed of sound is less than the speed of light. It is also found that the trace of the energy-momentum tensor is positive, the total mass is negative, and for collapsing shells the rate of change of circumference as measured by an observer riding on the shell is an increasing function of time. However, all these models have the strange geometric feature that the ''physical radius'' is a decreasing function of comoving radial coordinate

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper discusses cosmological Friedman models with the charged vacuum. It is shown that in this case nontrivial stable vacuum solutions exist for all three types of Friedman metric. The presence of a massive vector field for the vacuum changes the law of expansion at early stages of evolution of the universe. A method for construction of solutions with the charged vacuum for an O(N) invariant scalar multiplet is given

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author discusses some recent work on quantum cosmology which can be thought of as an attempt to determine the initial conditions for the universe. In this the universe is created by quantum tunneling from 'nothing'. By 'nothing' is meant a state with no classical space and time. Quantum cosmology is based on quantum gravity. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Instead of the 'cosmological principle' in 4-dim theory, the idea of an 'attractor' is introduced in a higher-dimensional cosmology in order to understand why our universe is the present one, i.e. (the 4-dim Friedmann universe; F4) x (a constant internal space; K). Two examples are presented. One is the S2-monopole compactification in 6-dim, N=2 supergravity coupled to Yang-Mills and matter fields, and the other is the Calabi-Yau compactification in 10-dim, N=1 supergravity coupled to the Yang-Mills field with the curvature squared term (Rμνρσ2 - 4Rμν2 + R2). In both cases, F4 x K is the attractor in the later stage of the universe and it is asymptotically unique apart from the time reversal ones. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

assignment="indexer">compactification</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02278" assignment="indexer">cosmology</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03326" assignment="indexer">expectation value</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05272" assignment="indexer">lagrangian function</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="13592" assignment="indexer">supergravity</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03747" assignment="upposted">functions</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="18029" assignment="upposted">unified-field theories</descriptor> </descriptors> <qualifiers> <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier> </qualifiers> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Instead of the 'cosmological principle' in 4-dim theory, the idea of an 'attractor' is introduced in a higher-dimensional cosmology in order to understand why our universe is the present one, i.e. (the 4-dim Friedmann universe; F<sup>4</sup>) x (a constant internal space; K). Two examples are presented. One is the S<sup>2</sup>-monopole compactification in 6-dim, N=2 supergravity coupled to Yang-Mills and matter fields, and the other is the Calabi-Yau compactification in 10-dim, N=1 supergravity coupled to the Yang-Mills field with the curvature squared term (R<sub>μνρσ</sub><sup>2</sup> - 4R<sub>μν</sub><sup>2</sup> + R<sup>2</sup>). In both cases, F<sup>4</sup> x K is the attractor in the later stage of the universe and it is asymptotically unique apart from the time reversal ones. (Auth.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="NL">Netherlands</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: A singularity avoided oscillating bouncing cosmological model

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1369-1375; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ACTION INTEGRAL; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; OSCILLATIONS; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTEGRALS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The one-loop contribution of the quantum effect of matter field to the effective action is evaluated. From this a semiclassical Einstein equation of the Friedmann universe is derived. With reasonable boundary condition a singularity avoided, time symmetric, oscillating, bouncing solution is obtained. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Horizon in Dirac cosmology and neutrino mass

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1381-1385; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (A2110)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DIRAC COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; NEUTRINOS; REST MASS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LEPTONS; MASS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The authors have suggested a theory to unify Dirac's Cosmology and General Relativity in a framework without introducing two time scale hypothesis (Milne's hypothesis). Two applications of this unified theory are discussed. Firstly, the horizon problem of Rindler (in the very early universe the size of causally connected domain is much smaller than the effective size of the universe) can be solved. Secondly, the influence of the neutrino rest mass on Dirac's cosmology is investigated. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A class of stationary rigidly rotating perfect fluids in General Relativity is investigated. This class which is characterized by zero Simon tensor contains only the Wahlquist solution and its limits. It is shown how a recently given solution follows from the Wahlquist solution by a limiting procedure. (author)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.content: Canonical perturbation theory in linearized general relativity theory

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CANONICAL TRANSFORMATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; PERTURBATION THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; RADIATIONS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Canonical perturbation theory in linearized general relativity theory is developed. It is shown that the evolution of arbitrary dynamic value, conditioned by the interaction of particles, gravitation and electromagnetic fields, can be presented in the form of a series, each member of it corresponding to the contribution of certain spontaneous or induced process. The main concepts of the approach are presented in the approximation of a weak gravitational field

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Aspect, A. (Centre Univ. d'Orsay, Orsay)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Comment on ''a classical model of EPR experiment with quantum mechanical correlations and Bell inequalities''

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Frontiers of nonequilibrium statistical physics

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Moore, G.T.; Scully, M.O; p. 185-189; 1986; p. 185-189; Plenum Press; New York, NY (USA); NATO advanced study institute on nonequilibrium quantum statistical mechanics; Santa Fe, NM (USA); 3-16 Jun 1984

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1110)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BELL THEOREM; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; CORRELATION FUNCTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPERIMENT PLANNING; FORECASTING; MEASURE THEORY; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTIZATION; QUANTUM MECHANICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; MECHANICS; PLANNING

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author states that ''It is impossible to mimick the quantum mechanical predictions for the EPR correlations, with a reasonable classical-looking model, in the spirit of Einstein's ideas''. The author feels that if he is wrong somebody could make a classical model (i.e. following the laws of classical physics) mimicking all the quantum mechanical predictions for the EPR correlations. He attempts to show that it is not the case for Barut's model for the following reasons: the first version of his model is classical, but doesn't mimick at all an EPR type experiment; and by reinterpretation one can get a model that does mimick the experiment, but this model is no longer ''reasonably classical looking'' since it involves negative probabilities. The claim is put in the form of a challenge. It is shown that the model under discussion can be reinterpreted by adding a chip converting the continuous outputs into two-valved outputs

meta.content: January 1986

<descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03747" assignment="upposted">functions</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05908" assignment="upposted">planning</descriptor> </descriptors> <qualifiers> <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier> </qualifiers> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The author states that ''It is impossible to mimick the quantum mechanical predictions for the EPR correlations, with a reasonable classical-looking model, in the spirit of Einstein's ideas''. The author feels that if he is wrong somebody could make a classical model (i.e. following the laws of classical physics) mimicking all the quantum mechanical predictions for the EPR correlations. He attempts to show that it is not the case for Barut's model for the following reasons: the first version of his model is classical, but doesn't mimick at all an EPR type experiment; and by reinterpretation one can get a model that does mimick the experiment, but this model is no longer ''reasonably classical looking'' since it involves negative probabilities. The claim is put in the form of a challenge. It is shown that the model under discussion can be reinterpreted by adding a chip converting the continuous outputs into two-valved outputs</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The problem of the weakest possible boundary conditions for the positive-energy theorem is discussed. Examples of asymptotically flat (in some sense) metrics violating this theorem are given. A class of metrics which have well defined infinite Arnowitt-Deser-Misner mass is presented. (author)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIMENSIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATION; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SPACE-TIME; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Using a multiparameter definition of space-time perturbation in a (4+n)-dimensional flat space, the question of identification gauge invariance of the background metric is examined. It is shown that when the allowed identification gauge transformations are given by rotations in the parameter space, then the background metric is invariant. A possible association with Kaluza--Klein theory is also examined

meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ALGORITHMS; ANGULAR MOMENTUM; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; SPACE-TIME; TIME DEPENDENCE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A rigorous version of the quadrupole radiation formula is derived using the characteristic initial value formulation of a general relativistic fluid space-time. Starting from initial data for a Newtonian fluid, an algorithm is presented that determines characteristic initial data for a one-parameter family of general relativistic fluid space-times. At the initial time, a one-parameter family of space-times with this initial data osculates the evolution of the Newtonian fluid and has leading order news function equal to the third time derivative of the transverse Newtonian quadrupole moment

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Imperfect fluid sources to the Schwarzschild exterior solution are studied under the assumption that the metric coefficients g00 and g11 of the interior solution satisfy the relation g00 g11 = -1. It was found that the core of such a distribution is gravitationally repulsive provided the energy density is positive

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Knutsen, H. (Stavanger College of Engineering, Box 2527, Ullandhaug, 4001 Stavanger, Norway)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On the physical properties of a nonquadratic solution for the McVittie metric

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(1) p. 159-164; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jan 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; COORDINATES; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; PRESSURE GRADIENTS; PULSATIONS; SPHERES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A particular class of McVittie's new nonquadratic solutions is examined with respect to its physical characteristics. It is found that center regularity is not compatible with negative pressure and density gradients. These solutions also have the strange geometric feature that the physical radius is a decreasing function of comoving radial coordinate. Models for nonstatic ''gaseous'' spheres (i.e., the density rho vanishes at the outer surface of the perfect fluid sphere together with the pressure p) have been constructed. The global motion is studied, and it has been found that pulsations are not possible. It is shown, however, that the density and pressure gradients are both negative. The pressure and the density are thus positive within the boundary of these ''gaseous'' spheres, and it is also seen that the density is increasing for contracting models. For the layers close to the outer boundary, it is shown that the pressure is increasing when the sphere is contracting. The speed of sound is thus real, and it is further seen that this speed is less than the speed of light. It is found that there exist bouncing models where the rate of change of circumference as measured by an observer riding on the boundary of the ''gaseous'' sphere is zero just at the moment when the sphere starts its reexpansion

meta.content: January 1987

Models for nonstatic ''gaseous'' spheres (i.e., the density rho vanishes at the outer surface of the perfect fluid sphere together with the pressure p) have been constructed. The global motion is studied, and it has been found that pulsations are not possible. It is shown, however, that the density and pressure gradients are both negative. The pressure and the density are thus positive within the boundary of these ''gaseous'' spheres, and it is also seen that the density is increasing for contracting models. For the layers close to the outer boundary, it is shown that the pressure is increasing when the sphere is contracting. The speed of sound is thus real, and it is further seen that this speed is less than the speed of light. It is found that there exist bouncing models where the rate of change of circumference as measured by an observer riding on the boundary of the ''gaseous'' sphere is zero just at the moment when the sphere starts its reexpansion</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Logunov, A.A.; Loskutov, Yu.M.; Chugreev, Yu.V. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Does GRT explain gravitational effects?

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Ob'yasnyaet li OTO gravitatsionnye ehffekty?

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Teoreticheskaya i Matematicheskaya Fizika; v. 69(3) p. 328-340; ISSN 0564-6162; CODEN TMFZA; Dec 1986; For English translation see the journal Theoretical and Mathematical Physics (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MINKOWSKI SPACE; RED SHIFT; RELATIVITY THEORY; TEST PARTICLES; UNCERTAINTY PRINCIPLE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that the relativistic theory of gravity (GTR) unambigously predicts gravitational effects while general relativity (GR) does not. For some effects the ambiguity is revealed in the first order in the gravitational constant G and for others in the second order. Absence in GR of conservation laws of energy-momentum and angular momentum of matter and gravitational field taken together and also its inability to predict gravitational phenomena with certainty make it necessary to reject GR as a physical theory

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Equivalence between fourth-order theories of gravity and general relativity: Possible implications for the cosmological singularity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 35(2) p. 480-482; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Jan 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS; RICCI TENSOR; SCALAR FIELDS; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A recent result has shown that the fourth-order theories of gravity with the action S = ∫ √-g (2Λ+R+(1/2)aR2)d4x are conformally equivalent to general relativity with a scalar field. This result may enlighten the validity of timelike and null convergence conditions in spatially homogeneous cosmological models with a diagonal metric. This approach points out that, under particular conditions, the timelike and null geodesics may be complete

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A solution of a pair of monopoles in 5D Kaluza-Klein theory without matter fields is given. The scale of the internal space is the same as that of the outer space. Its euclidean version is useful for calculating the wave function of the universe with monopoles. (orig.)

meta.content: Pfister, H.; Schedel, Ch. (Tuebingen Univ. (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Can gravitational attraction be compensated for by gravimagnetic effects

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(1) p. 141-147; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Jan 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MAGNETIC FIELDS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; ROTATION; SHELLS; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The paper concerns the compensation between gravitational attraction and gravimagnetic repulsion. To investigate this possibility, the authors have constructed a model whereby the gravitational attraction is counteracted by gravimagnetic repulsion for two relativistically rotating bodies, which can be thought of as being of laboratory size or stellar size. A weak field approximation is used, and only infinitely thin spherical shells of matter are considered in the model. The model's results indicate that gravimagnetism can reduce the gravitational attraction between relativistically rotating matter. (UK)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: Magnon, A.M.R. (Departement de Mathematiques, Universite de Clermont-Ferrand, 63170, Aubiere, France; Physics Department, University of Syracuse, Syracuse, New York 13244-1130; Institute for Theoretical Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, California 93106)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Existence and observability of spinor structure

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(6) p. 1364-1369; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jun 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; CPT THEOREM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GROUP THEORY; MAGNETIC MONOPOLES; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; SPINORS; TOPOLOGY; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; MONOPOLES; POSTULATED PARTICLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A mechanism by which space-time topological modifications could have been controlled, in the early universe or at the Planck length, to enable onset of spinor structure is investigated. This mechanism (based on a reshuffling of topological charges and related modification of characteristic classes) could provide a gravitational analog of the Aharonov--Susskind Gedankenexperiment proposed to detect relative rotation in the universe, spinor behavior, or to keep track of the two homotopy classes of the Lorentz Lie group. The space-time topology [and in particular the trivial (nontrivial) bundle structure at conformal null infinity] provide a labeling of the asymptotic Lorentz homotopy classes which originates in the first Chern class (enclosed magnetic mass) or in the parametrization of the second homology group, and gives rise to a necessary (and sufficient) condition for the existence of spinor structure. This underlines the intertwined roles of topology and curvature. The mechanism could also be viewed as an ''unwinding'' of gravitational magnetic monopoles with one asymptotic region into electric mass (black-hole) solutions with two asymptotic regions. In such situations a discrete PT symmetry could emerge from a continous transformation. Possible implications on the CPT theorem are mentioned

meta.content: January 1987

type="valid" key="07782" assignment="upposted">postulated particles</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A mechanism by which space-time topological modifications could have been controlled, in the early universe or at the Planck length, to enable onset of spinor structure is investigated. This mechanism (based on a reshuffling of topological charges and related modification of characteristic classes) could provide a gravitational analog of the Aharonov--Susskind Gedankenexperiment proposed to detect relative rotation in the universe, spinor behavior, or to keep track of the two homotopy classes of the Lorentz Lie group. The space-time topology [and in particular the trivial (nontrivial) bundle structure at conformal null infinity] provide a labeling of the asymptotic Lorentz homotopy classes which originates in the first Chern class (enclosed magnetic mass) or in the parametrization of the second homology group, and gives rise to a necessary (and sufficient) condition for the existence of spinor structure. This underlines the intertwined roles of topology and curvature. The mechanism could also be viewed as an ''unwinding'' of gravitational magnetic monopoles with one asymptotic region into electric mass (black-hole) solutions with two asymptotic regions. In such situations a discrete PT symmetry could emerge from a continous transformation. Possible implications on the CPT theorem are mentioned</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An open isotropic cosmological model at a nonzero cosmological constant with regard to spontaneous symmetry breaking and vacuum polarization is considered. It is shown that consideration of quantum effects leads to the lack of initial singularity and de Sitter expansion. The problem of the vacuum energy-momentum tensor corresponding to field deviations Φ having the quantum character is studied

meta.content: January 1986

meta.content: Black holes coupled to time-dependent scalar fields in the Kaluza-Klein theory

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; COUPLING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; METRICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SCALAR FIELDS; TIME DEPENDENCE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In terms of the five-dimensional Kaluza-Klein theory we study the time-dependent behaviour of a massless scalar field near the event horizon. It is shown that as a result of the nonlinear effect the scalar field increases with time. Consequently the extra dimension becomes fully visible. Some implications of this process are briefly discussed. (author)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Symmetric tensor spherical harmonics on the N-sphere and their application to the de Sitter group SO(N,1)

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(7) p. 1553-1566; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jul 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; DE SITTER GROUP; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GROUP THEORY; QUANTUM OPERATORS; RECURSION RELATIONS; SO GROUPS; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL HARMONICS; SYMMETRY; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; MATHEMATICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The symmetric tensor spherical harmonics (STSH's) on the N-sphere (S/sup N/), which are defined as the totally symmetric, traceless, and divergence-free tensor eigenfunctions of the Laplace--Beltrami (LB) operator on S/sup N/, are studied. Specifically, their construction is shown recursively starting from the lower-dimensional ones. The symmetric traceless tensors induced by STSH's are introduced. These play a crucial role in the recursive construction of STSH's. The normalization factors for STSH's are determined by using their transformation properties under SO(N+1). Then the symmetric, traceless, and divergence-free tensor eigenfunctions of the LB operator in the N-dimensional de Sitter space-time which are obtained by the analytic continuation of the STSH's on S/sup N/ are studied. Specifically, the allowed eigenvalues of the LB operator under the restriction of unitarity are determined. Our analysis gives a group-theoretical explanation of the forbidden mass range observed earlier for the spin-2 field theory in de Sitter space-time

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Global qualitative study of Bianchi universes in the presence of a cosmological constant

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(7) p. 1658-1666; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jul 1987

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; ORGANIZING; RELICT RADIATION; SINGULARITY; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MICROWAVE RADIATION; RADIATIONS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A particular class of nonempty spatially homogeneous orthogonal cosmologies of the Bianchi classification is considered in the presence of a nonzero cosmological constant Λ, i.e., cosmologies that can be transformed into a three-dimensional autonomous dynamical system: these are the axisymmetric type II, the pseudoaxisymmetric type VI0, and the (n/sup α//sub α/ = 0) types V, VI/sub h/ (including III = VI/sub -/1). A qualitative method to investigate such dynamical systems as a whole is presented. The qualitative study yields for every type a set of solutions of nonzero measure and another one of zero measure becoming isotropic in an infinite cosmological time when Λ>0

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: General relativity theory main insurmountable difficulties, leading to refusal from GRT are briefly summarized; relativistic theory of gravity (RTG) and its principles are presented. RTG is free from these difficulties and explains the whole set of gravitation observation and experimental data, predicting new representations about the Universe development and gravitational collapse RTG is a further development of Poincare, Minkowski, Einstein and Hilbert ideas. It strikes against dogmatism which is characteristic of RTG

meta.content: January 1986

xml:lang="en">General relativity theory main insurmountable difficulties, leading to refusal from GRT are briefly summarized; relativistic theory of gravity (RTG) and its principles are presented. RTG is free from these difficulties and explains the whole set of gravitation observation and experimental data, predicting new representations about the Universe development and gravitational collapse RTG is a further development of Poincare, Minkowski, Einstein and Hilbert ideas. It strikes against dogmatism which is characteristic of RTG</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="SU">USSR</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>
