meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On some peculiar space-times with spherical symmetry

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1140)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: As an extension of my old papers (1950 - 1) on a peculiar solution of the vacuum Einstein equations with the cosmological constant, i.e., Rμν = Λgμν, I reproduce the content of my Research Note (dated on October 6th, 1960) on some peculiar space-times with spherical symmetry, because it includes not only the Kantowski and Sach's solution of Einstein's equations for a dust fluid without Λ, but also the one for a dust fluid with Λ≠0, in addition to the case where Rμν = Λgμν (in similar to Nariai's solution). (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Accioly, A.J. (Sao Paulo Univ. (Brazil). Inst. de Fisica); Goncalves, A.T. (Rio de Janeiro Univ. (Brazil). Inst. de Fisica)

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Sao Paulo Univ. (Brazil). Inst. de Fisica

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Homogeneous space-time of Goedel type in higher-derivate gravity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Oct 1986; 13 p; IFUSP-P--604

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ACTION INTEGRAL; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE; VORTICES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A general theorem concerning any Goedel-type solution of higher-derivative gravity field equations, which may be produced by any reasonable physical source with a constant energy-momentum tensor, is analysed. The resulting class of metrics dependes on two parameters, one of which is related to the vorticity. A general class of solutions of Goedel-type space-time-homogeneous universes in the context of the higher-derivative theory is exhibited. This is the most general higher-derivative solution of such type of metric and includes all known solutions of Einstei's equations related to these geometries as a special case. A number of completely causal rotating models is also obtained. Some of them present the interesting feature of having no analogous in the framework of general relativity. (Author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

<descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A general theorem concerning any Goedel-type solution of higher-derivative gravity field equations, which may be produced by any reasonable physical source with a constant energy-momentum tensor, is analysed. The resulting class of metrics dependes on two parameters, one of which is related to the vorticity. A general class of solutions of Goedel-type space-time-homogeneous universes in the context of the higher-derivative theory is exhibited. This is the most general higher-derivative solution of such type of metric and includes all known solutions of Einstei's equations related to these geometries as a special case. A number of completely causal rotating models is also obtained. Some of them present the interesting feature of having no analogous in the framework of general relativity. (Author)</abstract> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="pt">Um teorema geral relacionado a qualquer solucao do tipo Goedel de equacoes de campo de gravitacao de derivadas mais altas, que podem ser produzidas por qualquer fonte fisica razoavel com um tensor de energia-momento constante, e analizado. A classe de metricas resultantes depende sobre dois parametros, um dos quais e relacionado a vorticidade. Uma classe geral de solucoes de universos de espaco-tempo homogeneo do tipo Goedel, no contexto da teoria de derivadas mais altas, e exibida. Essa e a solucao de derivadas mais altas mais geral desse tipo de metrica e inclui todas as solucoes conhecidas das equacoes de Einstein relacionadas a esses geometrias como um caso especial. Um numero de modelos de rotacao completamente causal e tambem obtido. Alguns deles apresentam a interessante caracteristica de nao ter nenhum analogo no contexto da relatividade geral. (L.C.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="BR">Brazil</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Propagation of gravitational waves through pressureless matter

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(2) p. 253-264; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Mar 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AMPLITUDES; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DENSITY; DISPERSION RELATIONS; DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; SPACE-TIME; VARIATIONS; VELOCITY; WAVE PROPAGATION; WKB APPROXIMATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The propagation of small-amplitude gravitational waves through pressureless matter ('dust') is investigated. After establishing the local linearisation stability of Einstein's equation for dust about any of its solutions, the Wentzel-Kramers-Brillouin (WKB) method is used to study the locally plane, linearised perturbations of an arbitrary background dust spacetime asymptotically for small wavelengths. The dispersion relation exhibits two modes. One is simply degenerate and represents gravitational waves, whereas the other is doubly degenerate and describes density and vorticity perturbations. The waves are shown to propagate along the null geodesics of the background; in leading WKB order their amplitudes behave as in vacuo. The rays associated with the matter mode are the worldlines of the background dust. In leading order the perturbations of density and 4-velocity vanish for both modes. (author)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On a general vacuum solution of fourth-order gravity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(3) p. 695-702; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 May 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; DE SITTER GROUP; DEGREES OF FREEDOM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The authors generalise the result derived for the Einstein theory with the cosmological term (the general asymptotic solution containing four arbitrary functions of three coordinates) to fourth-order gravity. For scale-invariant fourth-order gravity the expanding generalised de Sitter solution is found to be an attractor, i.e. for t → infinity an open neighbourhood of solutions approach this one. For (R + R2) gravity, one obtains an intermediate de Sitter stage with a high probability that is followed by a power-law Friedman stage. Finally, it is argued that the inclusion of ordinary inhomogeneously distributed matter does not alter these results. (author)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Exact solutions of classical and quantum fields in GR and quantum cosmology are obtained and applied to the solution of fundamental problems of cosmology. The problem of variations of fundamental constants and some relations among basic parameters of fundamental interactions are also discussed

meta.content: Matsuo, N. (Osaka Univ., Toyonaka (Japan). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Superstring thermodynamics and its application to cosmology

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Zeitschrift fuer Physik. C, Particles and Fields; v. 36(2) p. 289-304; ISSN 0170-9739; CODEN ZPCFD; Sep 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FREE ENERGY; PARTITION FUNCTIONS; STRING MODELS; SUPERSYMMETRY; THERMODYNAMICS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ENERGY; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SYMMETRY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The thermodynamics of superstring theories (SST-I, SST-II) and heterotic string theory and its application to the cosmology are studied. The free energy of superstring gas is calculated in the one-loop approximation and the stability of the extra torus dimensions is discussed. Assuming that the Einstein equation dictates the evolution of the universe, we show that matter dominated universe filled with massive particles would never be realized at the beginning of the universe, contrary to the naive expectation in the superstring cosmology. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Accioly, A.J. (5529364BR)

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Instituto de Fisica Teorica, Sao Paulo, SP (Brazil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A classical approach to higher-derivative gravity

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Two classical routes towards higher-derivative gravity theory are described. The first one is a geometrical route, starting from first principles. The second route is a formal one, and is based on a recent theorem by Castagnino et.al. [J. Math. Phys. 28 (1987) 1854]. A cosmological solution of the higher-derivative field equations is exhibited which in a classical framework singles out this gravitation theory. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1988

The first one is a geometrical route, starting from first principles. The second route is a formal one, and is based on a recent theorem by Castagnino et.al. [J. Math. Phys. 28 (1987) 1854]. A cosmological solution of the higher-derivative field equations is exhibited which in a classical framework singles out this gravitation theory. (author)</abstract> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="pt">Descrevem-se duas vias classicas para a teoria derivada da alta gravidade. A primeira e uma rota geometrica partindo dos primeiros principios. A segunda via e formal e e baseada no recente teorema de Castagnino. Uma solucao cosmologica das equacoes de campo derivadas da alta gravidade e apresentada, que em um simples sistema classico sai da teoria da gravitacao. (M.C.K.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="BR">Brazil</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Radiating spheres in general relativity with a mixed transport energy flow

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIFFUSION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; HYDRODYNAMICS; RADIATION STREAMING; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; METRICS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A seminumeric method by Herrera, Jimenez and Ruggeri is extended to handle the evolution of general relativistic spheres where diffusion and free streaming radiation processes coexist. It is shown when mixed-mode radiation is present a very different hydrodynamic picture emerges from the models previously considered in both radiation limits. Characteristic times for free streaming, hydrodynamics and diffusion processes are considered comparable. Hydrodynamics and radiation are strongly coupled and the particular equation of state of the model emerges as a very important element in the dynamic of the matter distribution. (author). 16 refs, 5 figs

meta.content: January 1989

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Exact solutions of the vacuum Einstein's equations allowing for two noncommuting Killing vectors

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1990; 13 p; IHEP-OTF--90-50; (IFVE-OTF--90-50); Submitted to J. Math. Phys.

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; METRICS; RICCI TENSOR; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; VECTORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Einstein's equations are written in the form of covariant gauge theory in two-dimensional space with binomial solvable gauge group, with respect to two noncommutative of Killing vectors. The theory is exact integrable in one-dimensional case and series of partial exact solutions are constructed in two-dimensional. 5 refs

meta.content: Rago, H.

meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Anisotropic spheres in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A prescription originally conceived for perfect fluids is extended to the case of anisotropic pressures. The method is used to obtain exact analytical solutions of the Einstein equations for spherically symmetric selfgravitating distribution of anisotropic matter. The solutions are matched to the Schwarzschild exterior metric. (author). 15 refs

meta.content: January 1991

meta.content: Exact self-consistent solutions to the interacting spinor and scalar field equations in Bianchi type-I space-time

meta.content: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS; SCALAR FIELDS; SELF-CONSISTENT FIELD; SPACE-TIME; SPINORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Self-consistent solutions to the system of spinor and scalar field equations in General Relativity are studied for the case of Bianchi type-I space-time. The absence of initial singularity should be emphasized for some types of solutions and also the isotropic mode of space-time expansion in some special cases. 3 refs

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A new derivation of the generalized field equation with a source term

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2210)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ACTION INTEGRAL; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; INTERACTION RANGE; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; NUCLEAR FORCES; PULSARS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; DISTANCE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INTEGRALS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A simple derivation of the generalized field equation with a source term is presented by restricting ourselves to a locally inertial frame. It reduces to Einstein's field equation when the Lagrangian is linear. Assuming the metric to be Minkowskian, simple solutions for the scalar curvature show the existence of a short range field and the emission of gravitational waves by objects which have strong field. (author). 10 refs

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1996

meta.content: Martins, M.R.; Silva, M.F.A. da (Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ), RJ (Brazil). Dept. de Fisica Teorica)

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Sociedade Brasileira de Fisica (SBF), Sao Paulo, SP (Brazil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Black hole from dark energy in 2+1 gravity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 2006; 6 p; 27. Brazilian national meeting on particle physics and fields; 27. Encontro nacional de fisica de particulas e campos; Aguas de Lindoia, SP (Brazil); 24-28 Sep 2006; INIS-BR--6097; ; Also available from http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0222-2.pdf; 5 refs.

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; SPACE-TIME; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In this paper we solve the Einsteins' field equations for a spherically symmetric anisotropic fluid, with kinematic self-similarity of the first kind, in spacetimes (2+1)-dimensional. Considering a null radial pressure we show that the fluid collapses forming a black hole in the end, even if it is constituted by phantom energy. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear

Dept. de Fisica Teorica</creator> <creator type="corporate">Sociedade Brasileira de Fisica (SBF), Sao Paulo, SP (Brazil)</creator> </creators> <identifiers> <identifier type="report-number">INIS-BR--6097</identifier> </identifiers> <availability inis="yes"> <contact>Available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:40102004; Also available from http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0222-2.pdf</contact> <copies> <copy href="http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:40102004">http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:40102004</copy> <copy href="http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0222-2.pdf">http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0222-2.pdf</copy> </copies> </availability> <conferences> <conference key=""> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">27. Brazilian national meeting on particle physics and fields</title> <title type="original" xml:lang="">27. Encontro nacional de fisica de particulas e campos</title> </titles> <locations> <location>Aguas de Lindoia, SP (Brazil)</location> </locations> <dates> <date value="2006-09-24/2006-09-28" sici-chronology="20060924/20060928">24-28 Sep 2006</date> </dates> </conference> </conferences> <notes> <note>5 refs.</note> </notes> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="S72">PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS</category> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="01114" assignment="indexer">black holes</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="20942" assignment="indexer">energy density</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="21731" assignment="indexer">energy-momentum tensor</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03151" assignment="indexer">equations of state</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04115" assignment="indexer">gravitational collapse</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07895" assignment="indexer">pressure dependence</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11448" assignment="indexer">three-dimensional calculations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09910" assignment="upposted">tensors</descriptor> </descriptors> <qualifiers> <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier> </qualifiers> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">In this paper we solve the Einsteins' field equations for a spherically symmetric anisotropic fluid, with kinematic self-similarity of the first kind, in spacetimes (2+1)-dimensional. Considering a null radial pressure we show that the fluid collapses forming a black hole in the end, even if it is constituted by phantom energy. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="BR">Brazil</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Yi-Ping, Qin (Center for Astrophysics, Guangzhou University, Guangzhou 510006, China Physics Department, Guangxi University, Nanning 530004 (China)), E-mail: ypqin@126.com

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A cosmological model with negative energy photons

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Chinese Physics. B; v. 19(1); ISSN 1674-1056; Jan 2010; [5 p.]; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1674-1056/19/1/019803; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; PHOTONS; SUPERNOVAE; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BINARY STARS; BOSONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; ERUPTIVE VARIABLE STARS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICS; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: According to recent investigations of states of quantum fields, we postulate that there exist negative energy photons in the universe. With this assumption, we find a solution of Einstein's equation without introducing the cosmological constant. A new and sizable type Ia supernovae sample is employed to perform a fit with our model and the conventional model. Both models can well account for the current type Ia supernovae observation and they are not distinguishable. With the new model, the cause of the accelerated expansion of the universe and the mechanism of the negative pressure existing in outer space can be explained in ordinary physical terms. (geophysics, astronomy and astrophysics)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2010

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: El-Menoufi, Basem Mahmoud; Ett, Benjamin; Kastor, David; Traschen, Jennie (Department of Physics, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003 (United States)), E-mail: bmahmoud@physics.umass.edu, E-mail: bett@physics.umass.edu, E-mail: kastor@physics.umass.edu, E-mail: traschen@physics.umass.edu

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Sum rule for the ADM mass and tensions in planar AdS spacetimes

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 30(20); ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRDG; 21 Oct 2013; [12 p.]; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/30/20/205006; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MASS; SCALING; SPACE-TIME; STRESSES; SUM RULES; SYMMETRY; VECTORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An asymptotically planar AdS spacetimes is characterized by its ADM mass and tensions. We define an additional ADM charge Q associated with the scaling Killing vector of AdS, show that Q is given by a certain sum over the ADM mass and tensions and that Q vanishes on solutions to the Einstein equation with Λ < 0. The sum rule for the mass and tensions thus established corresponds in an AdS/CFT context to the vanishing of the trace of the boundary stress tensor. We also show that an analogous sum rule holds for local planar sources of stress–energy in AdS. In a simple model consisting of a static, plane symmetric source we find that the perturbative stress–energy tensor must be tracefree. (paper)

meta.content: January 2013

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="GB13I3355" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="GB13I3355" type="journal" rn="45011370"> <publication> <languages> <language key="en">English</language> </languages> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Sum rule for the ADM mass and tensions in planar AdS spacetimes</title> </titles> <date value="2013-10-21" sici-chronology="20131021">21 Oct 2013</date> <physical-description>[12 p.]</physical-description> <country key="GB">United Kingdom</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">El-Menoufi, Basem Mahmoud</creator> <creator type="personal">Ett, Benjamin</creator> <creator type="personal">Kastor, David</creator> <creator type="personal">Traschen, Jennie</creator> <creator type="email">bmahmoud@physics.umass.edu</creator> <creator type="email">bett@physics.umass.edu</creator> <creator type="email">kastor@physics.umass.edu</creator> <creator type="email">traschen@physics.umass.edu</creator> <creator type="affiliation">Department of Physics, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003 (United States)</creator> </creators> <identifiers> <identifier type="doi">10.1088/0264-9381/30/20/205006</identifier> </identifiers> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:45011370; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/30/20/205006</contact> <copies> <copy href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/30/20/205006">http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/30/20/205006</copy> </copies> </availability> <notes> <note>Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)</note> </notes> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Classical and Quantum Gravity</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0264-9381</identifier> <identifier type="coden">CQGRDG</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 30(20)</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="S71">CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS</category> <category type="common" level="secondary" key="S72">PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS</category> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05885" assignment="indexer">mass</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08821" assignment="indexer">scaling</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09539" assignment="indexer">stresses</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09651" assignment="indexer">sum rules</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09719" assignment="indexer">symmetry</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10809" assignment="indexer">vectors</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09910" assignment="upposted">tensors</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">An asymptotically planar AdS spacetimes is characterized by its ADM mass and tensions. We define an additional ADM charge Q associated with the scaling Killing vector of AdS, show that Q is given by a certain sum over the ADM mass and tensions and that Q vanishes on solutions to the Einstein equation with Λ < 0. The sum rule for the mass and tensions thus established corresponds in an AdS/CFT context to the vanishing of the trace of the boundary stress tensor. We also show that an analogous sum rule holds for local planar sources of stress–energy in AdS. In a simple model consisting of a static, plane symmetric source we find that the perturbative stress–energy tensor must be tracefree. (paper)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Balakin, Alexander B.; Muharlyamov, Ruslan K.; Zayats, Alexei E. (Kazan Federal University, Department of General Relativity and Gravitation, Institute of Physics, Kazan (Russian Federation))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Electromagnetic waves in an axion-active relativistic plasma non-minimally coupled to gravity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 73(12); ISSN 1434-6044; Dec 2013; p. 1-19; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-013-2647-8

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; COUPLING; DAMPING; DE SITTER SPACE; DISPERSION RELATIONS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; PHASE VELOCITY; RELATIVISTIC PLASMA; SCALAR FIELDS; SELF-CONSISTENT FIELD; WAVE PROPAGATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PLASMA; RADIATIONS; SPACE; VELOCITY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We consider cosmological applications of a new self-consistent system of equations, accounting for a non-minimal coupling of the gravitational, electromagnetic and pseudoscalar (axion) fields in a relativistic plasma. We focus on dispersion relations for electromagnetic perturbations in an initially isotropic ultrarelativistic plasma coupled to the gravitational and axion fields in the framework of isotropic homogeneous cosmological model of the de Sitter type. We classify the longitudinal and transversal electromagnetic modes in an axionically active plasma and distinguish between waves (damping, instable or running), and nonharmonic perturbations (damping or instable). We show that for the special choice of the guiding model parameters the transversal electromagnetic waves in the axionically active plasma, non-minimally coupled to gravity, can propagate with the phase velocity smaller than the speed of light in vacuum, thus displaying a possibility for a new type of resonant particle-wave interactions. (orig.)

meta.content: January 2013

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Scalar fluctuations of the scalar metric during inflation from a non-perturbative 5D large-scale repulsive gravity model

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 73(10); ISSN 1434-6044; Oct 2013; p. 1-8; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-013-2598-0

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; DE SITTER SPACE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; FLUCTUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; HUBBLE EFFECT; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; QUASI PARTICLES; SCALAR FIELDS; SCALE INVARIANCE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGICAL FOLIATION; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MAPPING; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE; TRANSFORMATIONS; VARIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We develop a non-perturbative formalism for scalar metric fluctuations from a 5D extended version of general relativity in vacuum. In this work we concentrate our efforts on calculations valid on large cosmological scales, which are dominant during the inflationary phase of the universe. The resulting metric in this limit is obtained after implementing a planar coordinate transformation on a 5D Ricci-flat metric solution. We calculate the spectrum of these fluctuations with an effective 4D Schwarzschild-de Sitter spacetime on cosmological scales, which is obtained after we make a static foliation on the non-compact extra coordinate. Our results show how the squared metric fluctuations of the primordial universe become scale invariant with the inflationary expansion. (orig.)

meta.content: January 2013

meta.content: Stoica, Ovidiu Cristinel, E-mail: holotronix@gmail.com

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On the Weyl curvature hypothesis

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Annals of Physics (New York); v. 338; ISSN 0003-4916; CODEN APNYA6; Nov 2013; p. 186-194; S0003-4916(13)00171-1; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.aop.2013.08.002; Copyright (c) 2013 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam, The Netherlands, All rights reserved.; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; HYPOTHESIS; ISOTROPY; METRICS; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RELATIVITY THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Weyl curvature hypothesis of Penrose attempts to explain the high homogeneity and isotropy, and the very low entropy of the early universe, by conjecturing the vanishing of the Weyl tensor at the Big-Bang singularity. In previous papers it has been proposed an equivalent form of Einstein’s equation, which extends it and remains valid at an important class of singularities (including in particular the Schwarzschild, FLRW, and isotropic singularities). Here it is shown that if the Big-Bang singularity is from this class, it also satisfies the Weyl curvature hypothesis. As an application, we study a very general example of cosmological models, which generalizes the FLRW model by dropping the isotropy and homogeneity constraints. This model also generalizes isotropic singularities, and a class of singularities occurring in Bianchi cosmologies. We show that the Big-Bang singularity of this model is of the type under consideration, and satisfies therefore the Weyl curvature hypothesis. -- Highlights: •The singularities we introduce are described by finite geometric/physical objects. •Our singularities have smooth Riemann and Weyl curvatures. •We show they satisfy Penrose’s Weyl curvature hypothesis (Weyl=0 at singularities). •Examples: FLRW, isotropic singularities, an extension of Schwarzschild’s metric. •Example: a large class of singularities which may be anisotropic and inhomogeneous

<descriptor type="valid" key="08416" assignment="upposted">relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10060" assignment="upposted">thermodynamic properties</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The Weyl curvature hypothesis of Penrose attempts to explain the high homogeneity and isotropy, and the very low entropy of the early universe, by conjecturing the vanishing of the Weyl tensor at the Big-Bang singularity. In previous papers it has been proposed an equivalent form of Einstein’s equation, which extends it and remains valid at an important class of singularities (including in particular the Schwarzschild, FLRW, and isotropic singularities). Here it is shown that if the Big-Bang singularity is from this class, it also satisfies the Weyl curvature hypothesis. As an application, we study a very general example of cosmological models, which generalizes the FLRW model by dropping the isotropy and homogeneity constraints. This model also generalizes isotropic singularities, and a class of singularities occurring in Bianchi cosmologies. We show that the Big-Bang singularity of this model is of the type under consideration, and satisfies therefore the Weyl curvature hypothesis. -- Highlights: •The singularities we introduce are described by finite geometric/physical objects. •Our singularities have smooth Riemann and Weyl curvatures. •We show they satisfy Penrose’s Weyl curvature hypothesis (Weyl=0 at singularities). •Examples: FLRW, isotropic singularities, an extension of Schwarzschild’s metric. •Example: a large class of singularities which may be anisotropic and inhomogeneous</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Exact solutions in modified massive gravity and off-diagonal wormhole deformations

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(3); ISSN 1434-6044; Mar 2014; p. 1-16; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2781-y

meta.content: Journal article

meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.content: ANISOTROPY; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; DE SITTER SPACE; EFFECTIVE MASS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXACT SOLUTIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; POLARIZATION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SOLITONS; SPACE-TIME; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MASS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; QUASI PARTICLES; RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We explore off-diagonal deformations of 'prime' metrics in Einstein gravity (for instance, for wormhole configurations) into 'target' exact solutions in f(R,T)-modified and massive/bi-metric gravity theories. The new classes of solutions may, or may not, possess Killing symmetries and can be characterized by effective induced masses, anisotropic polarized interactions, and cosmological constants. For nonholonomic deformations with (conformal) ellipsoid/ toroid and/or solitonic symmetries and, in particular, for small eccentricity rotoid configurations, we can generate wormhole-like objects matching an external black ellipsoid--de Sitter geometries. We conclude that there are nonholonomic transforms and/or non-trivial limits to exact solutions in general relativity when modified/massive gravity effects are modeled by off-diagonal and/or nonholonomic parametric interactions. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2014

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Exact interior solutions in 2 + 1-dimensional spacetime

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(4); ISSN 1434-6044; Apr 2014; p. 1-7; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2845-z

meta.content: Journal article

meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTIC FUNCTIONS; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXACT SOLUTIONS; FLUIDS; METRICS; RED SHIFT; SPACE-TIME; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We provide a new class of exact solutions for the interior in 2 + 1-dimensional spacetime. The solutions obtained for the perfect fluid model both with and without cosmological constant (Λ) are found to be regular and singularity free. It assumes very simple analytical forms that help us to study the various physical properties of the configuration. Solutions without Λ are found to be physically acceptable. (orig.)

meta.content: January 2014

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Microscopic thin-shell wormholes in magnetic Melvin universe

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(5); ISSN 1434-6044; May 2014; p. 1-8; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2889-0

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMIC GASES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; EQUATIONS OF STATE; LOCALITY; MAGNETIC FIELDS; METRICS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; STABILITY; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GASES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We construct thin-shell wormholes in the magnetic Melvin universe. It is shown that in order to make a TSW in the Melvin spacetime the radius of the throat cannot be larger than (2)/(B0), in which B0 is the magnetic field constant. We also analyze the stability of the constructed wormhole in terms of a linear perturbation around the equilibrium point. In our stability analysis we scan a full set of the Equation of States such as Linear Gas, Chaplygin Gas, Generalized Chaplygin Gas, Modified Generalized Chaplygin Gas, and Logarithmic Gas. Finally we extend our study to the wormhole solution in the unified Melvin and Bertotti-Robinson spacetime. In this extension we show that for some specific cases, the local energy density is partially positive but the total energy which supports the wormhole is positive. (orig.)

meta.content: January 2014

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravity's Rainbow induces topology change

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(5); ISSN 1434-6044; May 2014; p. 1-11; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2884-5

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; FEYNMAN DIAGRAM; FLUCTUATIONS; GRAVITONS; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGY; VARIATIONAL METHODS; WAVE FUNCTIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; DIAGRAMS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; INFORMATION; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS; SPACE; VARIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In this work, we explore the possibility that quantum fluctuations induce a topology change, in the context of Gravity's Rainbow. A semiclassical approach is adopted, where the graviton one-loop contribution to a classical energy in a background spacetime is computed through a variational approach with Gaussian trial wave functionals. The energy density of the graviton one-loop contribution, or equivalently the background spacetime, is then let to evolve, and consequently the classical energy is determined. More specifically, the background metric is fixed to be Minkowskian in the equation governing the quantum fluctuations, which behaves essentially as a backreaction equation, and the quantum fluctuations are let to evolve; the classical energy, which depends on the evolved metric functions, is then evaluated. Analyzing this procedure, a natural ultraviolet cutoff is obtained, which forbids the presence of an interior spacetime region, and this may result in a multiply connected spacetime. Thus, in the context of Gravity's Rainbow, this process may be interpreted as a change in topology, and in principle it results in the presence of a planckian wormhole. (orig.)

assignment="upposted">radiations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10799" assignment="upposted">variations</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">In this work, we explore the possibility that quantum fluctuations induce a topology change, in the context of Gravity's Rainbow. A semiclassical approach is adopted, where the graviton one-loop contribution to a classical energy in a background spacetime is computed through a variational approach with Gaussian trial wave functionals. The energy density of the graviton one-loop contribution, or equivalently the background spacetime, is then let to evolve, and consequently the classical energy is determined. More specifically, the background metric is fixed to be Minkowskian in the equation governing the quantum fluctuations, which behaves essentially as a backreaction equation, and the quantum fluctuations are let to evolve; the classical energy, which depends on the evolved metric functions, is then evaluated. Analyzing this procedure, a natural ultraviolet cutoff is obtained, which forbids the presence of an interior spacetime region, and this may result in a multiply connected spacetime. Thus, in the context of Gravity's Rainbow, this process may be interpreted as a change in topology, and in principle it results in the presence of a planckian wormhole. (orig.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="DE">Germany</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We simplify and extend the construction of half-BPS solutions to 11-dimensional supergravity, with isometry superalgebra D(2,1;γ) + D(2,1;γ). Their space-time has the form AdS3 x S3 x S3 warped over a Riemann surface Σ. It describes near-horizon geometries of M2 branes ending on, or intersecting with, M5 branes along a common string. The general solution to the BPS equations is specified by a reduced set of data (γ, h, G), where γ is the real parameter of the isometry superalgebra, and h and G are functions on Σ whose differential equations and regularity conditions depend only on the sign of γ. The magnitude of γ enters only through the map of h,G onto the supergravity fields, thereby promoting all solutions into families parametrized by vertical stroke γ vertical stroke. By analyzing the regularity conditions for the supergravity fields, we prove two general theorems: (i) that the only solution with a 2-dimensional CFT dual is AdS3 x S3 x S3 x R 2, modulo discrete identifications of the flat R 2, and (ii) that solutions with γ < 0 cannot have more than one asymptotic higher-dimensional AdS region. We classify the allowed singularities of h and G near the boundary of Σ, and identify four local solutions: asymptotic AdS4/Z2 or AdS7' regions; highly-curved M5-branes; and a coordinate singularity called the ''cap''. By putting these ''Lego'' pieces together we recover all known global regular solutions with the above symmetry, including the self-dual strings on M5 for γ <0, and the Janus solution for γ > 0, but now promoted to families parametrized by vertical stroke γ vertical stroke. We also construct exactly new regular solutions which are asymptotic to AdS4/Z2 for γ < 0, and conjecture that they are a different superconformal limit of the self-dual string. Finally, we construct exactly γ > 0 solutions with highly curved M5-brane regions, which are the formal continuation of the self-dual string solutions across the decompactification point at γ = 0. (Copyright copyright 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH and Co. KGaA, Weinheim)

We also construct exactly new regular solutions which are asymptotic to AdS4/Z2 for γ < 0, and conjecture that they are a different superconformal limit of the self-dual string. Finally, we construct exactly γ > 0 solutions with highly curved M5-brane regions, which are the formal continuation of the self-dual string solutions across the decompactification point at γ = 0. meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Classically, unimodular gravity is known to be equivalent to General Relativity (GR), except for the fact that the effective cosmological constant Λ has the status of an integration constant. Here, we explore various formulations of unimodular gravity beyond the classical limit. We first consider the non-generally covariant action formulation in which the determinant of the metric is held fixed to unity. We argue that the corresponding quantum theory is also equivalent to General Relativity for localized perturbative processes which take place in generic backgrounds of infinite volume (such as asymptotically flat spacetimes). Next, using the same action, we calculate semiclassical non-perturbative quantities, which we expect will be dominated by Euclidean instanton solutions. We derive the entropy/area ratio for cosmological and black hole horizons, finding agreement with GR for solutions in backgrounds of infinite volume, but disagreement for backgrounds with finite volume. In deriving the above results, the path integral is taken over histories with fixed 4-volume. We point out that the results are different if we allow the 4-volume of the different histories to vary over a continuum range. In this ''generalized'' version of unimodular gravity, one recovers the full set of Einstein's equations in the classical limit, including the trace, so Λ is no longer an integration constant. Finally, we consider the generally covariant theory due to Henneaux and Teitelboim, which is classically equivalent to unimodular gravity. In this case, the standard semiclassical GR results are recovered provided that the boundary term in the Euclidean action is chosen appropriately

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: theory due to Henneaux and Teitelboim, which is classically equivalent to unimodular gravity. In this case, the standard semiclassical GR results are recovered provided that the boundary term in the Euclidean action is chosen appropriately

meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGY; COUPLING; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; PHYSICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In this paper, we investigate the perturbations in matter bounce induced from Lee-Wick lagrangian with the involvement of non-minimal coupling to the Einstein Gravity. We find that this extra non-minimal coupling term can cause a red-tilt on the primordial metric perturbation at extremely large scales. It can also lead to large enhancement of reheating of the normal field particles compared to the usual minimal coupling models

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2010

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS; CONFORMAL MAPPING; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; NUMERICAL SOLUTION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MAPPING; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; PHYSICS; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We consider issues related to the conformal mapping between the Einstein and Jordan frames in f(R) cosmology. We consider the impact of the conformal transformation on the gauge of a perturbed system and show that unless the system is written in a restricted set of gauges the mapping could produce an inconsistent result in the target frame. Newtonian gauge lies within the restricted group but synchronous gauge does not. If this is not treated carefully it could in principle contaminate numerical calculations

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2012

meta.content: Spectral methods in general relativity and large Randall-Sundrum II black holes

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; BLACK HOLES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MASS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CALCULATION METHODS; EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; METRICS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RELATIVITY THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Using a novel numerical spectral method, we have found solutions for large static Randall-Sundrum II (RSII) black holes by perturbing a numerical AdS5-CFT4 solution to the Einstein equation with a negative cosmological constant Λ that is asymptotically conformal to the Schwarzschild metric. We used a numerical spectral method independent of the Ricci-DeTurck-flow method used by Figueras, Lucietti, and Wiseman for a similar numerical solution. We have compared our black-hole solution to the one Figueras and Wiseman have derived by perturbing their numerical AdS5-CFT4 solution, showing that our solution agrees closely with theirs. We have obtained a closed-form approximation to the metric of the black hole on the brane. We have also deduced the new results that to first order in 1/(−ΛM2), the Hawking temperature and entropy of an RSII static black hole have the same values as the Schwarzschild metric with the same mass, but the horizon area is increased by about 4.7/(−Λ)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2013

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Bampi, F.; Cianci, R. (Genoa Univ. (Italy). Ist. Matematico)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Comments on limits of space-times

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: International Journal of Theoretical Physics; v. 19(3) p. 211-215; ISSN 0020-7748; Mar 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; LIMITING VALUES; METRICS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A coordinate-dependent investigation of limits of space-times is given. Different kinds of limits are found and analyzed. A criterion selecting limits which appear to be nothing but 'technical tricks' is proposed. Finally, a method for generating new limits from a given family of metrics is examined. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Novello, M. (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro, Brasil); d'Olival, J.B.S. (Instituto de Fisica, Rio de Janeiro, Brasil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Nonlinear viscous cosmology

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Acta Physica Polonica. Series B; v. 11(1) p. 3-13; ISSN 0587-4254; Jan 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DEFORMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HYDRODYNAMICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; STOKES LAW; VISCOSITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We treat the galactic fluid, in the early epochs of the Universe, as a nonlinear Stokesian fluid. Some general comments on fluids with viscosity are made. Then we examine an exact solution and give a qualitative analysis for a Bianchi type-I cosmological model generated by a fluid whose viscosity depends quadratically on the deformation tensor. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Tipler, F.J. (Center for Theoretical Physics, University of Texas, Austin, Texas 78712)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Singularities from colliding plane gravitational waves

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(12) p. 2929-2932; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Dec 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COLLISIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A simple geometrical argument is given which shows that a collision between two plane gravitational waves must result in singularities. The argument suggests that these singularities are a peculiar feature of plane waves, because singularities are also a consequence of a collision between self-gravitating plane waves of other fields with arbitrarily small energy density

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Cooperstock, F.I.; Sarracino, R.S.; Bayin, S.S. (Victoria Univ., British Columbia (Canada). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The localisation of energy in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 14(1) p. 181-189; ISSN 0305-4470; Jan 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; ENERGY TRANSFER; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LOCALITY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The energy localisation in the case of spherical symmetry advanced previously is justified in reference to an exact interior solution which is a generalisation of the rho = constant Schwarzschild solution. This reveals the inadequacy of the Tolman expression for localisation which also fails to provide the correct total mass for a system which exhibits certain discontinuities. A generalised localisation expression for arbitrary static systems is proposed for further consideration. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Schaefer, G.; Dehnen, H. (Fakultaet fuer Physik der Universitaet Konstanz, D-7750 Konstanz, Postfach 5560, West Germany)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational radiation by the thermal phonons of a solid

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(10) p. 2129-2136; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 May 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACKBODY RADIATION; CROSS SECTIONS; CYLINDERS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY SPECTRA; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; NEUTRON STARS; PHONONS; TENSORS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; QUASI PARTICLES; RADIATIONS; SPECTRA; STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Gravitational radiation by the phonons of a freely vibrating thin elastic cylinder is calculated in the high-frequency limit. For thermal excitation of the phonons the spectral energy distribution is found to be a blackbody one multiplied by the small opalescence factor (32/105)(MG/c2R)(c0/c)3. With the help of thermodynamic equilibrium considerations the resonance integral for the absorption cross section of the cylinder is deduced in the high-frequency limit. The application of the result to a neutron star is discussed

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Aichelburg, P.C.; Gueven, R.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Can charged black holes have a superhair

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC CHARGES; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR FIELD; KERR METRIC; O GROUPS; RARITA-SCHWINGER THEORY; SPACE-TIME; SUPERGRAVITY; SUPERSYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DYNAMICAL GROUPS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; METRICS; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The spin 3/2 perturbations of the Kerr-Newman black holes are analyzed by linearizing the field equations of O(2) extended supergravity with respect to the spin 3/2 fields. The equations governing the spin 3/2 fields in Kerr-Newman geometry are decoupled and separated. All solutions that cannot be brought to zero by the supersymmetry transformations are shown to satisfy the generalized s = +- 3/2 Teukolsky equations. The stationary solutions of these equations are not regular and hence cannot provide a new hair for the black holes. This generalizes the previous results obtained for the uncharged rotating black holes. However, it is also pointed out that the particular case where the electric charge equals the mass must be excluded from the argument. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

xml:lang="en">The spin 3/2 perturbations of the Kerr-Newman black holes are analyzed by linearizing the field equations of O(2) extended supergravity with respect to the spin 3/2 fields. The equations governing the spin 3/2 fields in Kerr-Newman geometry are decoupled and separated. All solutions that cannot be brought to zero by the supersymmetry transformations are shown to satisfy the generalized s = +- 3/2 Teukolsky equations. The stationary solutions of these equations are not regular and hence cannot provide a new hair for the black holes. This generalizes the previous results obtained for the uncharged rotating black holes. However, it is also pointed out that the particular case where the electric charge equals the mass must be excluded from the argument. (Auth.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="AT">Austria</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Field strenght copies in general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: nd; 15 p; INIS-MF--7396

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; SO-3 GROUPS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; SO GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Considering the SO(3,1) local, internal, transformations as the gauge group of general relativity, the possibility of having different affine connections (potentials) generating the same internal curvature (field strenght) is studied. Explicit examples of 'copies' are exhibited. The possibility to extend the concept of 'copy' to more general geometries is discussed. (Author)

Explicit examples of 'copies' are exhibited. The possibility to extend the concept of 'copy' to more general geometries is discussed. (Author)</abstract> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="pt">Estuda-se considerando as transformacoes SO(3,1) local e interna como um grupo de gauge de relatividade geral, a possibilidade de ter-se diferentes conexoes afins (potenciais) gerando a mesma curvatura interna (forca de campo). Exibem-se exemplos explicitos de 'copias'. Discute-se a possibilidade de extender o conceito de 'copia' a geometria mais gerais. (L.C.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="BR">Brazil</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Time-dependent, finite, rotating universes

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; ROTATION; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Three new classes of finite, homogeneous and nonsingular solutions of Einstein's equations which have time-dependent expansion, shear and rotation are presented. The t-constant sections are of Bianchi type IX. The source of these geometries is a fluid which has not been thermalized. (Author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: On the multipole expansion for stationary space-times

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; MULTIPOLES; SPACE-TIME; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is proved that a stationary, asymptotically flat space-time is (in a precise sense) analytic in a neighbourhood of spatial infinity. This implies that there exists a multipole expansion. Its terms are shown to be uniquely determined by the Geroch-Hansen multipole moments. (author)

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Rauch, R.; Shaw, J.C.; Nieh, H.-T. (State Univ. of New York, Stony Brook (USA). Inst. for Theoretical Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Birkhoff's theorem for ghost-free, tachyon-free R+R2+Q2 theories with torsion

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(4) p. 331-354; ISSN 0001-7701; Apr 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; P INVARIANCE; SCALARS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SO-3 GROUPS; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; TACHYONS; TORSION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; METRICS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; SO GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The conditions under which the class of ghost-free, tachyon-free R+R2+Q2 theories with torsion satisfy Birkhoff's theorem are investigated. A weakened Birkhoff theorem is proved requiring an additional assumption of parity invariance for two Lagrangians one of which contains torsion squared terms in addition to curvature squared terms. For another Lagrangian, also containing torsion squared terms, a weakened Birkhoff theorem requiring the additional assumptions is shown to satisfy a weakened Birkhoff theorem requiring only the additional assumption of constant scalar curvature. In addition the explicit dependence of torsion on parity noninvariant quantities is displayed. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04114" assignment="indexer">gravitation</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05272" assignment="indexer">lagrangian function</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07106" assignment="indexer">p invariance</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08818" assignment="indexer">scalars</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08872" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild metric</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12194" assignment="indexer">so-3 groups</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09363" assignment="indexer">spherical configuration</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09748" assignment="indexer">tachyons</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10351" assignment="indexer">torsion</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02148" assignment="upposted">configuration</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03080" assignment="upposted">elementary particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03747" assignment="upposted">functions</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04834" assignment="upposted">invariance principles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05490" assignment="upposted">lie groups</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07782" assignment="upposted">postulated particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09222" assignment="upposted">so groups</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09721" assignment="upposted">symmetry groups</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The conditions under which the class of ghost-free, tachyon-free R+R<sup>2</sup>+Q<sup>2</sup> theories with torsion satisfy Birkhoff's theorem are investigated. A weakened Birkhoff theorem is proved requiring an additional assumption of parity invariance for two Lagrangians one of which contains torsion squared terms in addition to curvature squared terms. For another Lagrangian, also containing torsion squared terms, a weakened Birkhoff theorem requiring the additional assumptions is shown to satisfy a weakened Birkhoff theorem requiring only the additional assumption of constant scalar curvature. In addition the explicit dependence of torsion on parity noninvariant quantities is displayed. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Denardo, G. (Trieste Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica Teorica; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Trieste (Italy)); Spallucci, E. (Trieste Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica Teorica)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Observer-dependent effects in a uniform electrovacuum space-time

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 23(6) p. 223-226; ISSN 0024-1318; 7 Oct 1978

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; LIGHT CONE; SPACE-TIME; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The physical meaning of a uniform electrovacuum metric is discussed. In particular, it is shown that the presence of a thermal spectrum is a purely observer-dependent effect. It is also obtained a coordinate transformation which cancels it and changes the metric into the usual form of the Bertotti Robinson space-time. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1978

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Spokoiny, B.L. (AN SSSR, Moscow. Inst. Teoreticheskoj Fiziki)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The effect of the electromagnetic fields on the evolution of homogeneous cosmological models near the singularity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(3) p. 279-291; ISSN 0001-7701; Mar 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; FLUIDS; METRICS; OSCILLATIONS; ROTATION; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Homogeneous cosmological models of all Bianchi types with a general (nondiagonal) metric are considered near the singularity. The spaces are filled with an arbitrary sourceless six-component electromagnetic field (EMF) and a perfect fluid at rest. It is shown that in the general case the models of types VI0, VII0, VIII, and IX have an oscillatory regime. The models of all the other types have Kasner asymptotics. The main result of the present paper is the derivation of the law of rotation of the Kasner axes. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Isenberg, J. (California Univ., Berkeley (USA). Dept. of Mathematics); Moncrief, V. (Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The existence of constant mean curvature foliations of Gowdy 3-tours spacetimes

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 86(4) p. 485-494; ISSN 0010-3616; Oct 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; SURFACES; TOPOLOGY; TOROIDAL CONFIGURATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANNULAR SPACE; CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We consider the class of smooth, maximally extended, globally hyperbolic, vacuum, Gowdy spacetimes on T3xR and prove that these spacetimes are globally foliated by space-like, constant mean curvature hypersurfaces. Our results can easily be extended to cover electrovac solutions of the same symmetry type and can probably be extended to cover other spacetime topologies as well. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

Our results can easily be extended to cover electrovac solutions of the same symmetry type and can probably be extended to cover other spacetime topologies as well.
