meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Frieman, J.A.; Will, C.M. (Institute of Theoretical Physics, Stanford University)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Evolution of perturbations in an inflationary universe

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Astrophysical Journal; v. 259(2) p. 437-441; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Aug 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; QUANTUM MECHANICS; RELATIVITY THEORY; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We analyze the evolution of inhomogeneous density perturbations in a model of the very early universe that is dominated for a time by a constant energy density of a false quantum-mechanical vacuum, with rho/sub v/approx.(1015 GeV/k)4. During this period, the universe inflates exponentially and supercools exponentially, until a phase transition back to the true vacuum reheats the matter and radiation. We focus on the physically measurable, coordinate-independent modes of inhomogeneous perturbations of this model and find that all modes either are constant or are exponentially damped during the inflationary era

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="US8226359" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="US8226359" type="journal" rn="14735221"> <publication> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Evolution of perturbations in an inflationary universe</title> </titles> <date value="1982-08-15" sici-chronology="19820815">15 Aug 1982</date> <country key="US">United States</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Frieman, J.A.</creator> <creator type="personal">Will, C.M.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">Institute of Theoretical Physics, Stanford University</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:14735221</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Astrophysical Journal</title> <title type="abbreviated">Astrophys. J</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0004-637X</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 259(2) p. 437-441.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1500" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02278" assignment="indexer">cosmology</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02717" assignment="indexer">disturbances</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="20942" assignment="indexer">energy density</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08124" assignment="indexer">quantum mechanics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08416" assignment="indexer">relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05945" assignment="upposted">mechanics</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We analyze the evolution of inhomogeneous density perturbations in a model of the very early universe that is dominated for a time by a constant energy density of a false quantum-mechanical vacuum, with rho/sub v/approx.(10<sup>15</sup> GeV/k)<sup>4</sup>. During this period, the universe inflates exponentially and supercools exponentially, until a phase transition back to the true vacuum reheats the matter and radiation. We focus on the physically measurable, coordinate-independent modes of inhomogeneous perturbations of this model and find that all modes either are constant or are exponentially damped during the inflationary era</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Calvani, M. (Padua Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Astronomia); Turolla, R. (International School for Advanced Studies, Trieste (Italy))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Singularities in the delta = 3 Tomimatsu-Sato space-time

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 28(14) p. 492-496; ISSN 0024-1318; 2 Aug 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; KERR METRIC; MASS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The existence of singularities outside the equatorial plane is investigated. We show that when the specific angular momentum a exceeds the mass m of the source, there are six ring singularities, while when a<m the singularities lie only in the equatorial plane. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Whereas asymptotically flat spacetimes are usually assumed to admit a spacelike maximal Cauchy hypersurface, it is shown that such hypersurfaces do not always exist, by giving explicit counter-examples. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Herrera, L.; Jimenez, J. (Universidad Central de Venezuela, Caracas. Dept. de Fisica)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The complexification of a non-rotating sphere: an extension of the Newman-Janis algorithm

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1017-1022; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ALGORITHMS; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Since the discovery of the Kerr metric there have been many attempts to find a matter distribution that could be matched to it. With this aim the authors employ a procedure given by Newman and Janis, by means of which one can derive the Kerr metric from the Schwarzschild metric. The procedure is applied to a spherical symmetric metric which contains the internal Schwarzschild solution for a perfect fluid as a special case. The new metric can be matched at the surface of the source to the exterior Kerr metric. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Zhu Shichang (Department of Physics, Shanghai Teachers College, China)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The expansion of void inhomogeneous cosmological model

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1391-1398; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; MASS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The low-density region in Tolman inhomogeneous cosmic model is called Tolman void. In this paper the expansions of mass invariable void and mass variable void are discussed respectively. The conclusion is that the expansion parameter of Tolman void is smaller than Hubble parameter of cosmological background. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Finn, L.S. (California Inst. of Tech., Pasadena (USA))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: g-modes of non-radially pulsating relativistic stars: the slow-motion formalism

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society; v. 222(2) p. 393-416; ISSN 0035-8711; CODEN MNRAA; 15 Sep 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1530)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; NEUTRON STARS; PULSATING VARIABLE STARS; PULSATIONS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; STAR MODELS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; RADIATIONS; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A new formalism, designed explicitly for the numerical study of g-modes of non-rotating, perfect-fluid, relativistic stars, is presented. The formalism is based on the analysis of Thorne and Campolattaro, (1967, Astrophys. J., 149,591) but with: (i) a choice of perturbation variables more suited to the numerical analysis of the low-frequency g-mode pulsations, (ii) the introduction of an instantaneous-gravity approximation that replaces the boundary condition of outgoing gravitational radiation at infinity by a non-radiative, Newtonian-like boundary condition, and (iii) an energy principle for determining the damping time of a mode due to gravitational radiation. The new formalism is applied to the study of g-mode pulsations of neutron star models with a polytropic equation of state. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="GB8700148" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="GB8700148" type="journal" rn="18034111"> <publication> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">g-modes of non-radially pulsating relativistic stars: the slow-motion formalism</title> </titles> <date value="1986-09-15" sici-chronology="19860915">15 Sep 1986</date> <country key="GB">United Kingdom</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Finn, L.S.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">California Inst. of Tech., Pasadena (USA)</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:18034111</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</title> <title type="abbreviated">Mon. Not. R. Astron. Soc</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0035-8711</identifier> <identifier type="coden">MNRAA</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 222(2) p. 393-416.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1530" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03558" assignment="indexer">fluid mechanics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04116" assignment="indexer">gravitational radiation</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="06579" assignment="indexer">neutron stars</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="20399" assignment="indexer">pulsating variable stars</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08047" assignment="indexer">pulsations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08415" assignment="indexer">relativistic range</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="18625" assignment="indexer">star models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03117" assignment="upposted">energy range</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05945" assignment="upposted">mechanics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08188" assignment="upposted">radiations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09459" assignment="upposted">stars</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12357" assignment="upposted">variable stars</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A new formalism, designed explicitly for the numerical study of g-modes of non-rotating, perfect-fluid, relativistic stars, is presented. The formalism is based on the analysis of Thorne and Campolattaro, (1967, Astrophys. J., 149,591) but with: (i) a choice of perturbation variables more suited to the numerical analysis of the low-frequency g-mode pulsations, (ii) the introduction of an instantaneous-gravity approximation that replaces the boundary condition of outgoing gravitational radiation at infinity by a non-radiative, Newtonian-like boundary condition, and (iii) an energy principle for determining the damping time of a mode due to gravitational radiation. The new formalism is applied to the study of g-mode pulsations of neutron star models with a polytropic equation of state. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Logunov, A.A.; Loskutov, Yu.M.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Gosudarstvennyj Komitet po Ispol'zovaniyu Atomnoj Ehnergii SSSR, Serpukhov. Inst. Fiziki Vysokikh Ehnergij

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Relativistic theory of gravitation and nonuniqueness of the predictions of general relativity theory

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MINKOWSKI SPACE; RED SHIFT; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; TEST PARTICLES; UNCERTAINTY PRINCIPLE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that while the predictions of relativistic theory of gravitation (RTG) for the gravitational effects are unique and consistent with the experimental data available, the relevant predictions of general relativity theory are not unique. Therewith the above nonuniqueness manifests itself in some effects in the first order in the gravitational interaction constant in others in the second one. The absence in GRT of the energy-momentum and angular momentum conservation laws for the matter and gravitational field taken together and its inapplicability to give uniquely determined predictions for the gravitational phenomena compel to reject GRT as a physical theory

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Barut, A.O.; Meystre, P. (Max planck Institute, Garching)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A classical model of EPR experiment with quantum mechanical correlations and Bell inequalities

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Frontiers of nonequilibrium statistical physics

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Moore, G.T.; Scully, M.O; p. 139-143; 1986; p. 139-143; Plenum Press; New York, NY (USA); NATO advanced study institute on nonequilibrium quantum statistical mechanics; Santa Fe, NM (USA); 3-16 Jun 1984

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1110)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BELL THEOREM; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; CORRELATION FUNCTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HIDDEN VARIABLES; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM MECHANICS; STATISTICAL MECHANICS; WAVE FUNCTIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper presents a simple model of a classical break-up process in which the correlation E(a,b) of the components A and B of the spins of the to subsystems along directions a and b gives precisely the quantum mechanical result - cos(a /SUP ./ b). The model is ''local'', but the normalization procedure of correlation functions in terms of hidden variables is different from that used in deriving Bell's inequalities. A discretization procedure of the classical spins is given which reproduces fully the dichotomous quantum mechanical results both for probabilities and for correlation functions. This procedure illustrates clearly the difference between quantum and classical spins and provides a possible intuitive picture for the notion of the reduction of the wave function

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Experimental tests of extra dimensions

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Phys. Lett., B; v. 186(1) p. 29-32; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 26 Feb 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CANONICAL DIMENSION; COUPLING CONSTANTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; TESTING

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SCALE DIMENSION

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Spherically symmetric solutions of general relativity in higher dimensions are tested. We find that the existence of extra dimensions is compatible with the classical tests of general relativity, which place almost no restrictions on the parameters involved. The models studied fail to explain the geological data concerning the apparent variability of the gravitational constant with the distance. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Evolution of disturbances in inflationary Universe

meta.content: Ehvolyutsiya vozmushchenij v inflyatsionnoj Vselennoj

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; METRICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The problem of the behaviour of the Universe metrics scalar disturbances in the gravitation theory with higher derivatives is solved. It is shown that heterogeneities generated from quantum flutuations can prove to be sufficient for the formation of galaxies. Restrictions for the theory parameters resulting from observations are found

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Chandrasekhar, Subrahmanyan (Chicago Univ., IL (USA)); Ferrari, Valeria (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On the dispersion of cylindrical impulsive gravitational waves

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 412(1842) p. 75-91; ISSN 0080-4630; CODEN PRLAA; 8 Jul 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CYLINDRICAL CONFIGURATION; DISPERSION RELATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; PULSES; REFLECTION; SHOCK WAVES; SINGULARITY; WAVE PACKETS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An exact solution, describing the dispersion of a wave packet of gravitational radiation, having initially (at time t = O) an impulsive character, is analysed. The impulsive character of the wave-packet derives from the space-time being flat, except at a radial distance ω = ω1 (say) at t O, and the time-derivative of the Weyl scalars exhibiting delta-function singularities at ω=ω1, when t → O. The principal feature of the dispersion is the development of a singularity of the metric function, v, and of the Weyl scalar, PSI2, when the wave, after reflection at the centre, collides with the still incoming waves. The evolution of the metric functions and of the Weyl scalars, as the dispersion progresses, is illustrated graphically. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

A</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0080-4630</identifier> <identifier type="coden">PRLAA</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 412(1842) p. 75-91.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1550" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="00389" assignment="indexer">analytical solution</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02451" assignment="indexer">cylindrical configuration</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02706" assignment="indexer">dispersion relations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04117" assignment="indexer">gravitational waves</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08060" assignment="indexer">pulses</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08400" assignment="indexer">reflection</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09036" assignment="indexer">shock waves</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09152" assignment="indexer">singularity</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10919" assignment="indexer">wave packets</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02148" assignment="upposted">configuration</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">An exact solution, describing the dispersion of a wave packet of gravitational radiation, having initially (at time t = O) an impulsive character, is analysed. The impulsive character of the wave-packet derives from the space-time being flat, except at a radial distance ω = ω<sub>1</sub> (say) at t O, and the time-derivative of the Weyl scalars exhibiting delta-function singularities at ω=ω<sub>1</sub>, when t → O. The principal feature of the dispersion is the development of a singularity of the metric function, v, and of the Weyl scalar, PSI<sub>2</sub>, when the wave, after reflection at the centre, collides with the still incoming waves. The evolution of the metric functions and of the Weyl scalars, as the dispersion progresses, is illustrated graphically. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Mignemi, S. (International School of Advanced Studies, Trieste (Italy)); Wiltshire, D.L.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Spherically symmetric solutions in dimensionally reduced spacetimes

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We study static solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations in D=m+n+2 dimensions which have the following symmetries; the solutions are spherically symmetric in (m+2) dimensions, (or more generally the m-sphere is replaced by any arbitrary m-dimensional Einstein space), while the internal space is an arbitrary n-dimensional Einstein space. The global properties of all such solutions are derived by considering the equivalent dimensionally reduced system in (m+2) dimensions, and by using techniques from the theory of dynamical systems after a judicious choice of variables. Apart from the trivial case of the Schwarzschild solution with constant scalar field all solutions are found to contain naked singularities or else not to be asymptotically flat; as would be expected from the ''no hair'' theorems. (author). 27 refs, 2 figs

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1988

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Rahaman, Farook (Jadavpur University, Department of Mathematics, Kolkata, West Bengal (India)); Kuhfittig, P.K.F. (Milwaukee School of Engineering, Department of Mathematics, Milwaukee, WI (United States)); Ray, Saibal (Government College of Engineering and Ceramic Technology, Department of Physics, Kolkata, West Bengal (India)); Islam, Nasarul (Danga High Madrasah, Department of Mathematics, Kolkata, West Bengal (India))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Possible existence of wormholes in the galactic halo region

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(2); ISSN 1434-6044; Feb 2014; p. 1-7; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2750-5

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUILIBRIUM; METRICS; MILKY WAY; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; ROTATION; SCATTERING; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; WAVE PROPAGATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATTER; MOTION; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Two observational results, the density profile from simulations performed in the ΛCDM scenario and the observed flat galactic rotation curves, are taken as input with the aim of showing that the galactic halo possesses some of the characteristics needed to support traversable wormholes. This result should be sufficient to provide an incentive for scientists to seek observational evidence for wormholes in the galactic halo region. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2014

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Kuhfittig, Peter K.F. (Milwaukee School of Engineering, Department of Mathematics, Milwaukee, WI (United States))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational lensing of wormholes in the galactic halo region

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(3); ISSN 1434-6044; Mar 2014; p. 1-6; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2818-2

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; GRAVITATIONAL LENSES; MAGELLANIC CLOUDS; METRICS; MILKY WAY; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; VISIBLE RADIATION; WAVE PROPAGATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DISTRIBUTION; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; LENSES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATTER; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A recent study by Rahaman et al. has shown that the galactic halo possesses the necessary properties for supporting traversable wormholes, based on two observational results, the Navarro-Frenk-White density profile and the observed flat rotation curves of galaxies. Using a method for calculating the deflection angle pioneered by V. Bozza, it is shown that the deflection angle diverges at the throat of the wormhole. The resulting photon sphere has a radius of about 0.40 ly. Given the dark-matter background, detection may be possible from past data using ordinary light. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2014
